Miss Fern came up from Kentucky after being found as a stray and not reclaimed by her owner. She is being taught house manners and going through potty training and is making improvements. She’s hesitant to eat from a bowl but getting better each day, some treats she likes and others she completely ignores so definitely learning all she does and doesn't like. She's learning social cues from her foster siblings and is doing fantastic with both her canine and feline housemates. For now she ignores the cats and is starting to show playfulness with the dogs. Miss Fern walks well on a leash, loves snuggles with adults or children and her favorite place is cuddling close in bed or on the couch. She is kenneled/crated when her foster goes to work and does whine a little since she is trying to understand she won't be abandoned again. Overall with a little reviewing and kind words she is really blossoming to be the spoiled girl she should live out the rest of her life to be.https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdIhm84ql5mGPbUco-8Qx9k6382EfrXopjGbqUeFWDEcOKxRg/viewform?vc=0&c=0&w=1&fbclid=IwAR2M1XinlO5oFmVSCSlhO9huUMJIpVzZFqqym92jd_gsOiZuNLg0lkVJpQU

ADOPT ME ONLINE: https://ophrescue.org/dogs8124Hi! My name is Little Man Kosovo. I got really lucky when OPH brought me to the US from a shelter in Kosovo.- I am 1.5 years old and weigh 22 lbs. - Im crate trained and house broken- I rest quietly in my crate during the day and at night- I love to lay in the grass and roll around in it. - I love rope toys and playing tug o war with my foster brothers- I like head scratches and belly rubs and after we get to know each other Ill snuggle with you. - I am very smart and I am a fast learner but I am slow to trust people. I need my future family to be patient. I am still learning that people wont hurt me. - I need to live in a home with another dog. I have always been part of pack and I get a lot of my confidence from my fosters brothers. - I am very gentle and submissive I am looking for my forever family! Could that be you? If so apply today!To adopt this dog, or any OPH dog, fill out the simple online application at https://ophrescue.org Operation Paws for Homes, Inc. (OPH) rescues dogs of all breeds and ages from high-kill shelters in NC, VA, MD, and SC, reducing the numbers being euthanized. With limited resources, the shelters are forced to put down 50-90% of the animals that come in the front door. OPH provides pet adoption services to families located in VA, DC, MD, PA and neighboring states. OPH is a 501(c)(3) organization and is 100% donor funded. OPH does not operate a shelter or have a physical location. We rely on foster families who open their homes to give love and attention to each dog before finding a forever home.

Charley is 3 years old and has recently arrived in the USA from Kosovo. He is good with dogs, children and all people. Charley needs a home without cats.If interested in adopting please fill out our no obligation online application at www.puppypawsrescue.org Note: Our rescue requires that all adopter's current and prior animals are up-to-date on vaccinations (DHLPP & Rabies)  and preventatives (heartworm and flea and tick), unless there is a medical reason not allowing it. All animals in your household should be spayed or neutered unless medically indicated that they should not be or are currently still too young.

Sweet Petit is a 1.5 year old Border Collie mix from Kosovo. He can be a little shy around new people but just rub his head and he is all your’s, he melts! Put him in the yard and he gets the zoomies until he tires himself out and lays there. He is fully vaccinated, neutered and good with other dogs.

18M 40lb Ciara Kindly, our little mystery breed girl, Canaan Shiba mix from Kuwait.  Someone brought her to an area to sell her and when he could not, he just dumped her where she was found being chased by a pack of strays.  , she loves people and would especially love it if her family were around a lot because she is super affectionate.  Please apply, she's here waiting for you.From Ciara's Foster Mom:  Ciara is a highly intelligent energetic Canaan mix dog.  She is alert to her surroundings at ALL times and will bark loudly to let you know.  This is a breed trait so she is just doing her job.  It is up to you to let her know you are aware and in charge of the situation.  I tell her good girl, I am on it then good girl Quiet until she calms down.  Prior to coming to us she had very little training in basic commands.  She is doing very well with:  Quiet-  used above or for unnecessary barking  Come-  from short and medium distances with reward training  Sit/Stay-  from short distances with treat training.She is fully housetrained, she needs to go out very first thing in the morning.  She is crate trained as well and sleeps there at night.  Extremely active and needs room to run so a fenced yard is best.  She will let you know she is bored by whining and will go for the occasional slipper if left unoccupied.  I tell her no gently and exchange it for one of her toys.  She doesn’t fully understand the concept of play yet, but is doing very well fetching her snake toy and squeaky ball.  She even brings it back to you!  She attaches herself quickly and only wants to be with you.  Loves belly rubs and chin scratches are the best!  Cats, not so much.   Facebook: Zani's Furry Friends ZFF (weekly event posted here)Twitter: zanisff Instagram: zanisfurryfriendsPlease fill out an application http://zanisfurryfriends.org/applications.html and return via email to: dogs@zanisfurryfriends.org Many of us (cats/dogs) will be on display on Sundays, and sometimes on Saturdays--please ask which dogs will be there ahead of time by writing us at dogs@zanisfurryfriends.org and following us on FB. If you are seriously interested in adopting one of us in particular, please fill out an application by Friday so that we can be sure to be there.  Please come! And if you can't adopt, you can always donate via paypal to: dogs@zanisfurryfriends.orgPlease consider providing a home for more than one dog, especially if you are considering adopting a puppy. Dogs are pack animals and very much enjoy as well as need other dog company to learn to play, socialize and be good companion animals to people. The upside to this is that you won't feel as guilty leaving them alone and you get twice the love. Please come! And if you can't adopt, you can always donate!

This dog is a part of our Summer $25 Adoption Fee Promotion! In an effort to keep up with the high rescue demand this summer, we are discounting many dog adoption fees to $25! Note- standard adoption screening interview and reference checks still apply!COME MEET ADOPTABLE DOGS EVERY SATURDAY AND SUNDAY from 10AM - 4PM at the Homeward Trails Adoption Center- 11116 Fairfax Station Road, Fairfax Station VA 22039! **Note that puppies are in foster homes, not at the Adoption Center.In an effort to save more lives, HT is allowing expedited adoptions for certain animals if applicants bring required paperwork. You can bring your new family member home more quickly by bringing your current pets' vet records, a copy of your lease or landlord letter stating you are permitted to have pets, and photos of your home. Help us help you adopt more quickly!If you are interested in adopting this dog, please fill out our dog adoption questionnaire and e-mail it to Caintracey@hotmail.comPLEASE VISIT THIS WEBSITE TO FIND THE ADOPTION QUESTIONNAIRE: http://www.homewardtrails.org/adopt-a-pet/adoption-forms/Sophie is sweet, gentle and loving, and so very much wants and needs someone who will show her the same gentleness and love. She needs a small household, ideally a single owner, who can spend a good amount of time with her, at least initially, to help her adapt to her new home and give her a calm and peaceful place to hang out. Sophie's still very skittish and scares easily with unfamiliar sounds both inside and outside the home. So far she hasn't had any bathroom accidents in her fosters home. She does fine in her crate when her foster is not home but will whine if in her crate when someone's home. She's a tall dog so would do really well physically with a runner and avid outdoorsy person as well as a large, fully fenced back yard so she can enjoy the outdoors off leash in a secure, closed environment because she is considered a flight risk. She would love her new mom or dad to give her a lot of gentle touches and love, and lots of patience by seeing the world through her eyes. As of April 2019-Sophie is still looking for a home!Sophie has made great progress. She was rescued from Kuwait in 2018, saved from an awful life on the streets. Sophie has come a long way- she has finally put on weight and loves going for long walks. She would do best in a quiet neighborhood with someone who can help her with her leash manners (barking at people and other dogs). She absolutely loves to go for walks!Sophie is an independent girl who would prefer to be the sole queen of the home and only pet. She is gentle and loving family member. She is also housetrained, and not destructive in her foster home (she can be left loose with no issues). -- Adoption Coordinator: Tracey Cain Breed Estimate: Shepherd Mix Gender: Female Approximate weight: 50 lbs Approximate age: 4 years old Location: In foster Cratetrained: Yes Coat Type. Shepherd Personality: Skittish, but lovingThe adoption fee for this dog is $25. This fee INCLUDES spay/neuter and microchip. Every adopted Homeward Trails animal comes with 30 days of free pet health insurance. We are proud to partner with the following veterinarians who offer a free first exam for your animal, exclusively for HT adopters: Caring Hands Animal Hospital, Palisades Veterinary Clinic, Sunshine Animal Hospital and Clarendon Animal Care and all VCA Animal Hospitals.Additionally, any VCA hospital will cover illnesses up to $250 at no cost to any Homeward Trails adopter.We also provide a 30-minute phone consult with a professional dog trainer at Fur-Get Me Not within the first 30 days of adopting - just for HT adopters in the Arlington/Alexandria area. Start your new dog out on the right foot with this valuable, expert advice and guidance FREE!You can save animals like this one by becoming a foster! If you are interested in becoming a foster, please check out our information about fostering by visiting http://www.homewardtrails.org/foster-a-pet/dog-and-cat-foster-program/

** Coming to Rhode Island and will be at the PetSmart- Warwick adoption event on June 29th!!~~~~~Wren was removed from an abusive situation. He is 11 months old. He is an extremely sweet, happy go lucky German Shepherd! He is a with all good with dogs and kids. He can be a little mouthy but nothing a little training can’t help.~~~~~****Our adoption fees are $550. This fee includes the transportation of the pet from one of the organizations that we work with in LA or TN. Before joining us in RI all dogs are: spayed/neutered, microchipped, up to date on age-appropriate vaccines, and on de-wormers, flea/tick and heartworm prevention. In addition, all adults (6 months +) are heartworm tested and MUST be negative for both heartworm and microfilaria before transport. In addition to the above, all dogs must have a Certificate of Veterinary Inspection and be deemed healthy per USDA law in order to travel. Once they have been certified they are then transported via USDA transport services only, which is required by law. Keep in mind that we also offer a two week return policy for the return of a healthy dog that includes a full refund. We want to make sure that the adoption is a perfect fit for both you and the dog.If you would like more information about adopting please select \"More About Little Rhody Rescue\" where you will also find our online application if you'd like to proceed with the adoption process. Thank you!

Grizzly was found wandering around St. Landry Parish, LA along with two other dogs named Missie and Minnie.  Our rescue takes in numerous dogs from St Landry's Animal Shelter in Opelousas, LA where animal abuse and neglect is a persistent problem in this parish.  Economics and an antiquated view on animal care are major factors.  In the past, St. Landry Parish Animal Control euthanized more than 96% of the creatures it took in.  Progressive changes since 2014 have been made and there is a new mindset at the shelter.  Now, St Landry's works in concert with many rescue groups throughout the nation to relocate a vast majority of pets who find their way to the shelter. Minnie and Grizzly appear to be siblings as they highly resemble one another and seem to be about the same age, 3 months.  The shelter listed the 2 pups at 5 months, but when our vet examined them, he found they still had all their baby teeth.  They are quite tall for their age which may be why the shelter listed them as they did.  The third dog, Missie, was also listed at 5 months and was thought to be a sibling as well, but it turns out Missie is about 1.5 years old and she is actually smaller than the 2 pups!Grizzly has soft, expressive eyes that seem to look right into your heart.  He often looks to his humans for direction and assurance, and he will then flick his tail to and fro when you say, \"good boy!”   He is a shy, but happy fellow who loves all he meets after warming up to them.  He would do well with a canine mentor to show him the ropes and offer him security.Grizzly will be brought up-to-date on vaccinations and micro-chipped.  He is heartworm negative and will be ready for his forever family in mid July.   Adopters must commit to the spaying or neutering of their adopted pup before it reaches 1 year of age and must provide proof of neutering to SGRR.  Rescued dogs come with a range of needs - from behavioral to emotional to medical.  When approved applicants adopt such dogs, they agree to continue the rehabilitation we have begun.  If you are home most of the day, have an active life-style, and a sense of humor and would like to be part of Grizzly's rescue story, and have already been approved for adoption through SGRR, please contact Donna Toncic at: SunshineGoldens@gmail.com     to be considered to adopt Grizzly.           If not yet approved, please visit our website to learn more and to submit an online application:     http://sunshinegoldenrescue.com/adoption-info1.html  Please DO NOT use the ASK ABOUT button to contact us, about this dog, as that will delay our ability to respond to your inquiry.  Please direct any questions regarding your application status to:  ajpillinger@gmail.com   *  Since the early 2000’s, animal rescue workers have noticed an increasing phenomena called, “Black Dog Syndrome,” which is that black dogs tend to be adopted more slowly than dogs of other coloring.  As a result, there are more black dogs in shelters, and black dogs have a higher euthanization rate – purely because of the color of their coat!  In a recent survey done by the adoption website “Petfinder,” Petfinder member shelters and rescue groups reported that most pets are listed for 12.5 weeks on Petfinder, whereas, less-adoptable pets (such as black, senior, and special needs pets) spend almost four times as long on Petfinder. You may ask, \"what does this have to do with a Golden Retriever rescue?\"  Our rescue often goes a step further than basic rescue, by taking in dogs that might be thought of as “less adoptable” because of their physical condition.  We have expanded that to include these special black dogs, many often thought to be Golden mixes.  Since doing so, we have seen an overwhelming interest in these “black goldens,” and note that we begin receiving inquiries about them as son as we publish their pictures on our website!  Like all of our dogs, these pups are just looking for a family that can see beyond their coloring to their true “golden heartedness,” and to love them and make them their own!  Those who can, will be glad they did!    Thank you!About Our Rescue Before being approved to adopt, all potential adopters will be required to complete our online application and participate in our pre-adoption review process. The process includes the completion of an online application, a reference from the applicants' vet, a phone interview, and a visit to the applicants' home.  The application process helps us determine what type of Golden would be best suited for the applicants' life style.  In some cases, the specific dog you are interested in may have found a home before this process is complete or further assessment may indicate that this dog is not the right match for your family.  We are frequently getting new Goldens in need of a home, so we encourage you to apply and complete the application process so that when the right dog comes along you will be ready. The information provided on each dog is based on the observations of our vets, volunteers, fosters, and when available, trainers. While we do our best to report any and all issues, SGRR does not make any guarantees as to the health or temperament of any dog. Dogs evolve differently in different environments and we cannot predict with any certainty how the dog you adopt will behave and adapt in your home.SGRR Adoption Fees (subject to change)Puppies under 6 months   $650Young dogs 6 months - 6 years   $550Young dogs - Special Needs   $450Senior dogs 7 - 9  years   $450Seniors dogs 10 years and older   $350Senior dogs - Special Needs   $300Young Bonded Pairs   $850Senior Bonded Pairs   $750A contract is signed on the day of adoption.  Under the terms of the contract, all adopters are required to bring their SGRR dog to a vet within 7 business days.  All dogs receive basic veterinary care prior to adoption.  However, if an adopter's vet identifies an illness that an adopter is not willing to treat, then the dog may be returned and a full refund would be provided. Most of our dogs are fostered in private homes.  We do not have a facility to visit.  We are committed to our dogs before, during, and after adoption! To this end, the rescue retains an interest in each dog and our dogs can never be surrendered, re-homed, or sold. Should an adopter no longer be able to keep their SGRR dog, SGRR must be notified so that we can take the dog back into rescue and place it into another home. We reserve the right to remove a dog at any time should we find the adopter is no longer providing proper care.  Adopters agree to follow up visits as needed.  Please be a ray of light for this Sunshine dog and make a tax deductible donation toward medical care and other expenses.   Every cent of your generosity goes directly toward the care of a Sunshine dog.Please visit our website at: http://sunshinegoldenrescue.com  to learn more about our rescue and to make a Donation to support Sunshine Golden Retriever Rescue.  THANK YOU!

Every cent of your generosity goes directly toward the care of a Sunshine dog.Please visit our website at: http://sunshinegoldenrescue.com  to learn more about our rescue and to make a Donation to support Sunshine Golden Retriever Rescue. Our rescue takes in numerous dogs from St Landry's Animal Shelter in Opelousas, LA where animal abuse and neglect is a persistent problem in this parish.  Economics and an antiquated view on animal care are major factors.  In the past, St. Landry Parish Animal Control euthanized more than 96% of the creatures it took in.  Progressive changes since 2014 have been made and there is a new mindset at the shelter.  Now, St Landry's works in concert with many rescue groups throughout the nation to relocate a vast majority of pets who find their way to the shelter. Missie was found wandering around St. Landry Parish, LA along with two other dogs named Minnie and Grizzly.  Minnie and Grizzly appear to be siblings as they highly resemble one another and seem to be about the same age, 3 months.   Missie was thought to be a sibling as well, but it turns out Missie is about 1.5 years old, and she is actually smaller than the 2 pups!Missie LOVES to give hugs and get as close as she can to her human friends.  She is incredibly tender and is a nice, nice dog!  She would do well in a home with another dog who can mentor her and help her gain confidence.  But as long as she is by your side, that is fine with her.  Missie has a beautiful shiny black coat with fur that is a bit shorter than her friends' coats.  She is proof that good things come in small packages.  At about 38 lbs, she is the perfect size for just about anyone from apartment dwellers to those of us who are aging and can no longer manage a 70 lb dog. Missie is spayed, up-to-date on vaccinations, and micro-chipped.  Because her former owner did not keep her on heartworm preventative, Missie is being treated for heartworm.  She will be ready to come north in early August. Rescued dogs come with a range of needs - from behavioral to emotional to medical.  When approved applicants adopt such dogs, they agree to continue the rehabilitation we have begun.  If you have already been approved for adoption through SGRR and would like to be part of Missie's rescue story, please contact Donna Toncic at: SunshineGoldens@gmail.com     to be considered to adopt Missie.  * Since the early 2000’s, animal rescue workers have noticed an increasing phenomena called, “Black Dog Syndrome,” which is that black dogs tend to be adopted more slowly than dogs of other coloring.  As a result, there are more black dogs in shelters, and black dogs have a higher euthanization rate – purely because of the color of their coat!  In a recent survey done by the adoption website “Petfinder,” Petfinder member shelters and rescue groups reported that most pets are listed for 12.5 weeks on Petfinder, whereas, less-adoptable pets (such as black, senior, and special needs pets) spend almost four times as long on Petfinder. You may ask, \"what does this have to do with a Golden Retriever rescue?\"  Our rescue often goes a step further than basic rescue, by taking in dogs that might be thought of as “less adoptable” because of their physical condition.  We have expanded that to include these special black dogs, many often thought to be Golden mixes.  Since doing so, we have seen an overwhelming interest in these “black goldens,” and note that we begin receiving inquiries about them as son as we publish their pictures on our website!  Like all of our dogs, these pups are just looking for a family that can see beyond their coloring to their true “golden heartedness,” and to love them and make them their own!  Those who can, will be glad they did!    If not yet approved for adoption, please visit our website to learn more and to submit an online application:     http://sunshinegoldenrescue.com/adoption-info1.html  Please DO NOT use the ASK ABOUT button to contact us, about this dog, as that will delay our ability to respond to your inquiry.  Please direct any questions regarding your application status to:  ajpillinger@gmail.com   Thank you!About Our Rescue Before being approved to adopt, all potential adopters will be required to complete our online application and participate in our pre-adoption review process. The process includes the completion of an online application, a reference from the applicants' vet, a phone interview, and a visit to the applicants' home.  The application process helps us determine what type of Golden would be best suited for the applicants' life style.  In some cases, the specific dog you are interested in may have found a home before this process is complete or further assessment may indicate that this dog is not the right match for your family.  We are frequently getting new Goldens in need of a home, so we encourage you to apply and complete the application process so that when the right dog comes along you will be ready. The information provided on each dog is based on the observations of our vets, volunteers, fosters, and when available, trainers. While we do our best to report any and all issues, SGRR does not make any guarantees as to the health or temperament of any dog. Dogs evolve differently in different environments and we cannot predict with any certainty how the dog you adopt will behave and adapt in your home.SGRR Adoption Fees (subject to change)Puppies under 6 months   $650Young dogs 6 months - 6 years   $550Young dogs - Special Needs   $450Senior dogs 7 - 9  years   $450Seniors dogs 10 years and older   $350Senior dogs - Special Needs   $300Young Bonded Pairs   $850Senior Bonded Pairs   $750A contract is signed on the day of adoption.  Under the terms of the contract, all adopters are required to bring their SGRR dog to a vet within 7 business days.  All dogs receive basic veterinary care prior to adoption.  However, if an adopter's vet identifies an illness that an adopter is not willing to treat, then the dog may be returned and a full refund would be provided. Most of our dogs are fostered in private homes.  We do not have a facility to visit.  We are committed to our dogs before, during, and after adoption! To this end, the rescue retains an interest in each dog and our dogs can never be surrendered, re-homed, or sold. Should an adopter no longer be able to keep their SGRR dog, SGRR must be notified so that we can take the dog back into rescue and place it into another home. We reserve the right to remove a dog at any time should we find the adopter is no longer providing proper care.  Adopters agree to follow up visits as needed.  Please be a ray of light for this Sunshine dog and make a tax deductible donation toward medical care and other expenses.   Every cent of your generosity goes directly toward the care of a Sunshine dog.Please visit our website at: http://sunshinegoldenrescue.com  to learn more about our rescue and to make a Donation to support Sunshine Golden Retriever Rescue.  THANK YOU!

~~~~~Troy is a happy dog. He follows commands on the dime. He knows a long list of commands including play dead, sit, stay, release, come here and paw! He also gets along great with cats.~~~~~****Our adoption fees are $550. This fee includes the transportation of the pet from one of the organizations that we work with in LA or TN. Before joining us in RI all dogs are: spayed/neutered, microchipped, up to date on age-appropriate vaccines, and on de-wormers, flea/tick and heartworm prevention. In addition, all adults (6 months +) are heartworm tested and MUST be negative for both heartworm and microfilaria before transport. In addition to the above, all dogs must have a Certificate of Veterinary Inspection and be deemed healthy per USDA law in order to travel. Once they have been certified they are then transported via USDA transport services only, which is required by law. Keep in mind that we also offer a two week return policy for the return of a healthy dog that includes a full refund. We want to make sure that the adoption is a perfect fit for both you and the dog.If you would like more information about adopting please select \"More About Little Rhody Rescue\" where you will also find our online application if you'd like to proceed with the adoption process. Thank you!

Meet Sunny! He is about about four months old and weighs around 12 pounds. Given his looks, he probably has some hound in his mix. Sunny, his siblings, and their mom Summer were rescued from the Louisiana shelter they were surrendered to as an unwanted family. Given his age, Sunny’s ideal adopter will be home for the majority of the day and will continue to help Sunny build his confidence through positive new experiences and continued socialization with other dogs and people. His foster says, \"Sunny is a sweet and loving pup! He loves to snuggle up and has already learned ‘sit’. He is slowly getting used to his crate and potty training. He is good with other dogs and loves going on adventures! He is easy to train. Treats are the way to his heart along with antlers and toys.\"He is available to meet by appointment with an approved adopter in Hopkinton, MA. Please fill out an adoption application at browndogcoalition.com/adoption as a first step.-puppies may not be given as gifts or surprises-please thoughtfully discuss with your entire household the physical safety and financial and emotional responsibilities of a puppy BEFORE applying to adopt -the entire family must come to the adoption meeting -more information about our adoption process, application and adoption fee can be found at browndogcoalition.com

I have an Adoption Pending but hope you will consider one of our other great dogs.  Thank you!Our rescue takes in numerous dogs from St Landry's Animal Shelter in Opelousas, LA.   Animal abuse and neglect is a persistent problem in this parish - economics and an antiquated view on animal care are factors.  In the past, St. Landry Parish Animal Control euthanized more than 96% of the creatures it took in.  Progressive changes since 2014 have been made and there is a new mindset at the shelter.  Now, St Landry's works in concert with many rescue groups throughout the nation to relocate a vast majority of pets who find their way to the shelter.  Bella is another one of the dogs whose life has been saved!Bella is a sweet and petite Golden/Lab mix, or as we like to call them, \"black goldens!\"  :-)  She is thought to be about 18 months old and was picked up as a stray in St Landry's Parish, LA.  Sadly, no one came to claim Bella.  An animal shelter can be a very scary place, especially for a black dog, the least adopted color and most frequently euthanized.  Bella is lovable, and a bit shy when she first meets someone new, but she is a push-over for belly rubs!  She is good with other dogs, but has no known history with cats.  She weighs about 45 lbs and could probably stand to gain another 5 lbs or so.  She has a stunningly beautiful, glossy black coat and the kindest eyes you have ever seen. Our trainer is working with Bella on her leash skills.  In time, she will make an excellent walking or jogging buddy.  Bella will also learn basic commands, like sit, stay, and down.  She is spayed, up-to-date on vaccinations, and micro-chipped.  Because her former owner did not keep Bella on heartworm preventative, she is being treated for heartworm.  She will be ready to come north mid July.  This sweet girl is not going to last! Rescued dogs come with a range of needs - from behavioral to emotional to medical.  When approved applicants adopt such dogs, they agree to continue the rehabilitation we have begun.  If you would like to be part of Bella's rescue story, and you have already been approved for adoption through SGRR, please contact Donna Toncic at: SunshineGoldens@gmail.com     to be considered to adopt Bella.           If not yet approved, please visit our website to learn more and to submit an online application:     http://sunshinegoldenrescue.com/adoption-info1.html  Please DO NOT use the ASK ABOUT button to contact us, about this dog, as that will delay our ability to respond to your inquiry.  Please direct any questions regarding your application status to:  ajpillinger@gmail.com Black \"Goldens...?\"Since the early 2000’s, animal rescue workers have noticed an increasing phenomena called, “Black Dog Syndrome,” which is that black dogs tend to be adopted more slowly than dogs of other coloring.  As a result, there are more black dogs in shelters, and black dogs have a higher euthanization rate – purely because of the color of their coat!  In a recent survey done by the adoption website “Petfinder,” Petfinder member shelters and rescue groups reported that most pets are listed for 12.5 weeks on Petfinder, whereas, less-adoptable pets (such as black, senior, and special needs pets) spend almost four times as long on Petfinder. You may ask, \"what does this have to do with a Golden Retriever rescue?\"  Our rescue often goes a step further than basic rescue, by taking in dogs that might be thought of as “less adoptable” because of their physical condition.  We have expanded that to include these special black dogs, many often thought to be Golden mixes.  Since doing so, we have seen an overwhelming interest in these “black goldens,” and note that we begin receiving inquiries about them as son as we publish their pictures on our website!  Like all of our dogs, these pups are just looking for a family that can see beyond their coloring to their true “golden heartedness,” and to love them and make them their own!  Those who can, will be glad they did!    Thank you!About Our Rescue Before being approved to adopt, all potential adopters will be required to complete our online application and participate in our pre-adoption review process. The process includes the completion of an online application, a reference from the applicants' vet, a phone interview, and a visit to the applicants' home.  The application process helps us determine what type of Golden would be best suited for the applicants' life style.  In some cases, the specific dog you are interested in may have found a home before this process is complete or further assessment may indicate that this dog is not the right match for your family.  We are frequently getting new Goldens in need of a home, so we encourage you to apply and complete the application process so that when the right dog comes along you will be ready. The information provided on each dog is based on the observations of our vets, volunteers, fosters, and when available, trainers. While we do our best to report any and all issues, SGRR does not make any guarantees as to the health or temperament of any dog. Dogs evolve differently in different environments and we cannot predict with any certainty how the dog you adopt will behave and adapt in your home.SGRR Adoption Fees (subject to change)Puppies under 6 months   $650Young dogs 6 months - 6 years   $550Young dogs - Special Needs   $450Senior dogs 7 - 9  years   $450Seniors dogs 10 years and older   $350Senior dogs - Special Needs   $300Young Bonded Pairs   $850Senior Bonded Pairs   $750A contract is signed on the day of adoption.  Under the terms of the contract, all adopters are required to bring their SGRR dog to a vet within 7 business days.  All dogs receive basic veterinary care prior to adoption.  However, if an adopter's vet identifies an illness that an adopter is not willing to treat, then the dog may be returned and a full refund would be provided. Most of our dogs are fostered in private homes.  We do not have a facility to visit.  We are committed to our dogs before, during, and after adoption! To this end, the rescue retains an interest in each dog and our dogs can never be surrendered, re-homed, or sold. Should an adopter no longer be able to keep their SGRR dog, SGRR must be notified so that we can take the dog back into rescue and place it into another home. We reserve the right to remove a dog at any time should we find the adopter is no longer providing proper care.  Adopters agree to follow up visits as needed.  Please be a ray of light for this Sunshine dog and make a tax deductible donation toward medical care and other expenses.   Every cent of your generosity goes directly toward the care of a Sunshine dog.Please visit our website at: http://sunshinegoldenrescue.com  to learn more about our rescue and to make a Donation to support Sunshine Golden Retriever Rescue.  THANK YOU!

Evangeline is a 4 month old pup who LOVES the POOL. She will lie in it like it's a hot tub. She loves to play with the big dogs and might be too rough for smaller dogs. She is super submissive, belly up when she first meets you. She is gentle with toddlers, timid with men. She came to us with her siblings, Bayou and Creole, from a rescue in Louisiana. She is 90% on her house training and with a part time worker she will get proper socialization and training. She is a LOVE and is ready to give her all to you if you just invest a little time and training. Please apply online at http://www.saveadog.org/applytoadopt.asp and we will be in touch about our visiting hours. Please apply online at http://www.saveadog.org/applytoadopt.asp and we will be in touch about our visiting hours. No phone calls please.

Ruston is a beautiful puppy who came to us from Louisiana after having lived a very sheltered life without receiving adequate socialization. This means that the world can be a strange and scary place, especially new experiences in new environments. But we're thrilled to share that he's gained much confidence and is making great progress through patience, training, and learning the ropes from other dogs. He loves playing and goofing around with other dogs. His foster mom says \"Ruston is the happiest dog I've ever met. He just doesn't want to be touched unless he initiates it. He's made great strides, and even has started sleeping in bed with his foster mom, snoring away happily at the footof the bed\".Ruston is a polite boy in and out of the house. He is going to need a quiet, mature home alongside another dog and owners who have had dog experience, ideally shy dog experience, who can be his best advocate and understand he'll need to take his time and some help learning new things like leash training. Another dog is definitely necessary to show him the ropes of living in a home and feeling comfortable with people.  Ruston is currently spending time out of the shelter in a temporary foster home, so please email adopt@baypathhumane.org to find out more about this sweet boy!

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.Chrissy is 4 years old and between 10 and 11 pounds. She is a Yorkie blend female who comes to rescue from St Landry Parish Shelter in Louisiana. Chrissy is up to date on vaccines and will be spayed prior to placement in her forever home. Chrissy has done well at our veterinary partner with other dogs. She has been a little 'snappy' if you reach for her to pick her up, but we are hopeful that behavior will be resolved once she has been placed in a home where she can decompress and settle in and feel like you won't give up on her. For this reason, we recommend a home where if there are children, they are over the age of 10. If you would like to open your heart, arms and home to Chrissy, please put your application in here: http://www.rescuedogsrocknyc.org

Maybelle is a fun and spunky girl who is looking for her forever home. She loves to play outside and also loves to cuddle up on your lap. She is a 4yo hound mix who is good with male dogs or submissive female dogs. She loves her human and wants to make you proud! She came from LA where she had a pretty rough start to life, but she has put her past behind her and she cant wait to meet you!

Chester is a tall drink of southern water who made the long trip up from Louisiana to find his forever home. Everyone whose met Chester has described him as one big goober! He is young, energetic, and loves to give and get affection. He'll play with toys until he drops, especially the stuffy ones. He loves to go for walks in the woods and chase after tennis balls. We know Chester will greatly benefit from training classes. We can tell he's a smart boy, and training can help teach you appropriate ways to keep his brain busy and happy, while teaching him to be confident in his abilities. Chester seems to get along well with other playful dogs, but it always depends on how the meet goes. Chester is definitely an exuberant boy and would do best in a patient, adult-only home. Please come meet him today if you think you'd be a good fit!

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.Loretta is a petite Lab Blend female probably mixed with something small, as she is very tiny. We estimate her age right now to be 2 years and she is 14 pounds. Loretta came to rescue from St Landry Parish shelter in Louisiana with her 4 puppies. At first very shy and frightened, Loretta has blossomed into the sweetest and most loving little girl. She doesn't care for loud noises, so she will do best in a calm home in a very quiet suburb or rural area. She is good with people and has shown no aggression; she is only a little scared and may take some time to warm up to a new environment. She gets along with other dogs. She is a very special girl and we can’t wait to find her an amazing forever family! She is up to date on vaccines and will be spayed when medically appropriate. If you would like to adopt precious Loretta, please put your application in here: http://www.rescuedogsrocknyc.org

Meet Kaos!Kaos is a beautiful shepherd and staffy mix who was rescued from a kill shelter in south Louisiana. She was a high heartworm positive but has completed treatment and is now ready to find her forever family!Kaos has severe separation anxiety but is getting better. She CANNOT be crated but can be left in a room if needed. She has some resource guarding from life on the streets so would need to be fed separately. Treats and bones should probably also be given separately. Kaos is great with other dogs and cats and is very low key. She likes to spend time with her foster momma and is a bit of a Velcro dog. We think she would make a great therapy dog who could visit hospitals and nursing homes.Applications can be found at www.snarranimalrescue.org

Baby Girl and Little Man are a couple of Rat Terrier mixes that were rescued together from a kill shelter in southern Louisiana. They are approx. 15 pounds each and 4-5 years old. Initially they were ultra-shy but have come along way in foster care.They are both altered, up to date on vaccines and have been treated for HW. We are hoping to locate a stable, loving and committed home for them in the Northeast. Please email us at TheChiSociety@gmail.com to inquire about or apply for these two cuties!

Honeysuckle our black and tan little lady form the flower litter is ready for her forever home! Honeysuckle is one of 6 (the Flower Litter) that were saved from almost being destroyed in LA. To ensure a great begining all our adopted puppies at One Love Animal Rescue are required toattend puppy training classes. If you are looking to add puppy love and a whole lot of puppy kisses to your world please fill out an application at oneloveanimalrescue.orgTo be considered as this pet's adopter, please go to www.oneloveanimalrescue.org/adopt.html to complete your application.

Louie is gorgeous, one of 4 puppies, strays from Louisiana.  Very sweet,  had a bit of a rough start and may need a few minutes to feel comfortable with new situations but not long and then he is a total lovebug.  Currently about 28 pounds at 3 months old, we expect Louie may be about 75 pounds when grown.  Now in Maryland working on his housebreaking and leash skills, he is looking for a family to share his love with. His foster says he is very smart, learned sit very quickly. APPLICATION LINK   https://docs.google.com/forms/d/12OTN3QBcNJEXlyQM0GzTMrb5ErkjpgWV3MiSlUP0L64/The adoption fee for puppies less than 6 months old is $350, which includes the cost of routine vetting, including age appropriate vaccinations, worming, flea/tick preventative and spay/neuter. Puppies under 4 months of age may go to adoptive homes before they are spayed/neutered. Adopters who choose to adopt a puppy that has not yet been spayed/neutered are subject to an additional deposit of $100 (refundable upon proof of spay/neuter.) Included in the adoption fee, the rescue will arrange spay/neuter by a partner vet at the adopter's convenience when the puppy is between 4-6 months of age. It is the responsibility of the adopter to bring the adopted puppy back to the rescue vet for spaying/neutering or to send verification from another vet that the puppy had been spayed/neutered.  All of our dogs will be microchipped.Because our dogs are in foster homes, applications are required prior to setting up any appointments. Calling or emailing may delay your consideration. Find our application on our website, almosthomedogs.org or click link below to find our application. https://docs.google.com/forms/d/12OTN3QBcNJEXlyQM0GzTMrb5ErkjpgWV3MiSlUP0L64/edit?ts=5a7f738fWe are a non profit no kill 501 (c)3 rescue. Please understand that we do our best to describe our dogs but often we rescue them with virtually no information about them and often our best educated guess can be challenging. Currently check or cash is preferred payment.

Willow is a wonderful pup looking for a special home. Willow was saved from a high kill shelter in Louisiana when she was 4 yrs old. This girl almost faced death not once, but twice, but you wouldn’t know it.“Today, you wouldn’t know the journey she has been on. This happy go lucky affectionate girl knows all her commands, is fine in and out of a crate, and loves her people. She loves children and one of her favorite things is to find a patch of sunlight in the backyard and bath in it. This smart loving girl gives kisses and has figured out every puzzle game. She can be redirected from barking with treats and she has never destroyed anything. No counter surfing, no chewing on things that don’t belong to her, and she likes to be touching you, and when she truly trusts you she may even end up curled up in your lap or sleeping with you in bed.” This is an excerpt from her story and I would encourage everyone to read her entire story and see if she could be the right dog for your family! IF YOU ARE INTERESTED IN ADOPTING ONE OF OUR DOGS... please visit us at www.luslabs.org and fill out an adoption application.  Once submitted, one of our Adoption Coordinators will be in touch!

29 October: What more can I say about Matty. He is super sweet, and devoted, and is loving, funny, and affectionate. He does occasionally display his feral beginnings, but is easily managed. Matty will do best in a home with other dogs, and where the humans are patient and understanding.****22 September: Matty is currently one of the farm favorites. He is so sweet and gentle, he loves everyone and is a super cuddler. He has learned that people really like to pet and rub, and that that feels so very good. Matty will make such a wonderful companion for the right home.****UPDATE: 4 July -- Matty is a super sweet little guy who is just looking for love. A southern boy with an angel on his shoulder, Matty came to us from one of our partner organisations in Louisiana. Picked up as stray, Matty has obviously not had a lot of handling in his young life, and does take a day or two to trust, but he loves hanging out with his humans, and dogs, too!! Matty can be a little tough on cats, so a home without cats would be better for him (and the cats!).Matty is crate trained, appears to be housebroken, and is learning how to walk on leash. He will do best in a quiet home without young children (we don't really know how he is with little ones, though he was fine with a toddler outside here.), and , and would be happy with lots of walks and good play time.For more photos, please see our facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/mabcr.org. Each dog has an album there on the page.  You do not need to be a facebook subscriber to view the photos.Please read our procedures prior to making inquiry regarding this dog. Please go to our main website at www.mabcr.org for more information regarding the adoption of this or any dog from our rescue. Please note that while this dog is currently available, any dog on our site may have an adoption pending and may not be available to you at this time. The same dog may later become available if the adoption falls through. Our website www.mabcr.org will give you details on our adoption procedures as well as an application for adoption. An application must be submitted prior to 'matching' an adopter with a dog as all dogs do not fit into all homes. We pride ourselves in our adoption process, we take the time to get to know our adopters so that we can place a dog with them that they can enjoy for years to come.Please understand that we will not discuss dogs with individual adopters until after the application process is completed.Our rescue does not have a public facility, therefore there are no visiting hours. Appointments to visit with the available dogs are made after the application process has been completed by our staff.  To assist any dog within the MABCR organization, please consider making a donation to the general fund or to the medical fund. All dogs coming into our rescue are fully vetted (s/n and innoculations) prior to adoption.Rescuing animals is quite expensive. If you are unable to adopt, but would like to help this, or any other animal in our system, please consider a sponsorship donation. For information on our sponsorship program, please contact Sarah at SLR@mabcr.org.  DONATE ONLINE USING PAYPALThank you for your interest in Mid-Atlantic Border Collie Rescue.

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.New Arrival:- DANIEL is a great Beagle mix boy who came to us from a hoarding/abuse situation in Louisiana. He is slightly taller than a standard Beagle and weighs in at 35 lbs and is about 5 years old. When DANIEL arrived we noticed his left eye was very cloudy. Our eye vet confirmed that DANIEL had glaucoma and was blind in his left eye and, unfortunately, the pressure in that eye was 75 against a normal eye pressure of 10-20 mmHg! This would result in DANIEL being in quite a lot of pain! Since DANIEL had just been neutered and treated for heartworms it would not have been prudent to perform surgery to remove the eye. So we too the opportunity to drain the fluid from the eye and administer some eye medications hoping to lower DANIEL’s eye pressure. Unfortunately, after 2 weeks his pressure was still 68. While the standard solution use to be to just remove the eye in these cases, after consultation with DR Mohoric, we decided to try “Ciliary Boy Ablation (CBA) where they injected a medication into DANIEL’s eye to kill the cells that were producing the fluid that was responsible for the high pressures and high pain. Wee, I was ecstatic today when DANIEL’s eye pressure was “7”! So DANIEL is no longer in pain and was able to keep his eye, which is much more cosmetically pleasing.- So DANIEL is ready for adoption! He loves to gather lots of towels and blankets and make his own bed and, if possible, he would prefer it be on top of a table or in a chair.

I'm Horace and I come all the way from Louisiana! I am being treated for heartworm. I am not a fan of smaller dogs or cats, but I don't mind hanging out with the \"bigger kids.\"

Adonis is a young male catahoula leopard dog pup just rescued from Louisiana. He is definitely a striking pup and friendly! He needs his own home. As we work with him over the next week, will find out more about him.KNOW YOUR CATAHOULAS!The Louisiana Catahoula Leopard Dog once known as The Catahoula Cur is a medium to medium-large dog that is well muscled, and capable of performing a variety of tasks.The feet of the Catahoula are webbed very similar to that of a duck. Most dogs have a webbing between their toes, but, the web of a Catahoula is very prominent and extends almost to the end of the toes. This fully webbed foot enables the Catahoula to work soft marshy areas very easily, and aids them in being great swimmers.The eyes may be blue(glass), green, brown or amber. They may have two different colored eyes, or may have \"cracked\" eyes. An eye is considered cracked when two different colors appear within the same eye. This could be as much as half of the eye, or as little as a different colored streak running through the eye.The Catahoula is very wary of strangers but is at home with children. If a child and pup are allowed to grow together, you will not have to worry about your child. You will have a built in baby-sitter. As with any dog, you must be cautious when introducing him to new people. Catahoulas know what and whom they like, and I've found them to be an excellent judge of character. You will not be able to force this dog to like someone if his instincts tell him otherwise. His family comes first and that's who will receive his loyalty.The Catahoula is not an aggressive dog, but it is assertive. This dog will not tolerate being mishandled, mistreated, or attacked. It will defend itself to whatever means necessary. There are some breeders that refer to their dogs as aggressive dogs, but I have found that this is a reference to the manner in which they work. The Catahoula is a dog that will take charge when it is necessary. It is naturally protective of what and whom it thinks it owns.A Catahoula requires a minimum of one hour of running exercise each day, rain or shine. If the dog is kept outdoors, this is not a problem, but, if he is an indoor dog, he must get this exercise. Daily walks or runs in a yard are sufficient, but they are necessary. Since this dog has the inherent nature to herd and track game, he needs the exercise to release some of that pent up energy.You must be ready to teach and exercise a Catahoula. If not, he will eat your house. The Catahoula will not let you forget that you own a dog. If you do not have the time and energy it takes to train and exercise an active dog, then the Catahoula is not the dog for you. To describe what a Catahoula is like is almost impossible. You really have to own one to understand these dogs. Once you own one, you will be amazed that this dog already knows what you want, and what you are going to do. You will swear that the dog can read your mind, and he will out-think you, if given the chance.Adonis has a once in a lifetime chance of having a great home! Are you the perfect one for him? Please email larrylmurdock@gmail.com if you are the ONE! Also, please apply at www.blackjackrescue.orgThank you!

He's such a sweet, happy and playful boy, and he's sure to put a smile on your face. Sargent is a hound mix who is around 5-years old. He is in a foster home with other dogs and cats, and he gets along with everyone he meets. He loves plush toys and snuggling, and he would love to be in a home where he is allowed to cuddle on the couch with you. Sargent is housebroken, crate-trained, and walks well on a leash. He is learning to sit for a treat. Sargent is neutered, up-to-date on vaccines, and has been treated for heartworms. He would do well in almost any home, but would probably be best with older children. And, as a hound with an active nose, he'd be safest in a home with a securely fenced yard.

Tiny is a beagle that we think is about 4 years old.  Since relocating to Michigan from Louisiana, he has been working on his leash walking, crate training, and learning some commands.  He’s really been focused on playing with his doggie foster siblings and taking naps in the sun.  He’s made amazing strides learning to trust people, working on his surgical skills by unstuffing toys, and his yard inspector skills by looking for places to sneak out.  If you’re looking for someone to sing you a song while you get his dinner, Tiny can’t wait to meet you!  Tiny is neutered, micro-chipped, and up to date on all his vet care. Tiny is currently going through Heartworm Treatment but Hearts of Hope will provide this until completion. His adoption fee is $200. To adopt Tiny apply at www.rescueofhope.com/adoption-application

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.Name: FangieDOB: 4/7/2017Weight:Adoption Fee: $300Hi my name is Fangie! Yah, I know it’s kinda tricky to say so one of the kids in my foster home calls me Van Geese. I’m overflowing with personality and happy and curious and fast and spunky so my foster mom calls me Snickerdoodle. Then out of the blue she calls me Skippy! Well, it doesn’t matter much to me as long as the snuggles and cuddles keep coming! I came all the way up from Louisiana with my friend Abbee. I am potty trained on a scheduled and have also let my fosters know when I need (or want) to go outside. I love exploring the outdoors! Me and Abbee are crate trained however we are much more content to be cozied up next to each other. I greet everyone with a little dance. It’s pretty impressive how high I am able to jump, but just give me a little reminder and I’ll show you I’m a pro at sitting too! I get along okay with the two younger medium size dogs here but they don’t realize they are a lot bigger and I feel like I’m going to get trampled on when we try to play so I just stick with wrestling with Abbee. I’m interested in the cats but mom is trying to teach me to be respectful towards them. The kids here (9 & 12) our great napping spots! I like to let my fosters know when I hear something, but I don’t go on and on. Yep, I’m a good little guy! .Please note I must be adopted with my best friend Abbee: https://www.ruffstartrescue.org/animals/detail?AnimalID=14228287An adoption application is the best way to show your interest in an animal. I am quiet.My foster family has noticed that sometimes I get my \"second wind\" at 8:30-9:00 pm. My routine right now is as follows: awake about 6:30am and out for potty, have breakfast then back to bed with foster dad. Back up about 10:30 am another potty, potty on schedule is what's needed for me now, then I am left alone from about 2-4pm, potty when foster mom gets home. ALL OF OUR DOGS ARE IN PRIVATE FOSTER HOMES IN LOUISIANA AND/OR MAINE (or partnering humane society in Louisiana). BECAUSE WE DON'T WORK OUT OF A FACILITY, WE ARE NOT OPEN TO THE PUBLIC. THE FIRST STEP IN ADOPTING A DOG IS COMPLETION AND APPROVAL OF AN APPLICATION.  PLEASE VISIT OUR WEBSITE AT www.puppyloveme.org TO COMPLETE AN APPLICATION AND FOR MORE INFORMATION ABOUT OUR RESCUE  WE APPRECIATE YOUR TAX DEDUCTIBLE DONATION TO ASSIST IN OUR RESCUE MISSION.Our all inclusive adoption fee is $395.  Our dogs are fully vetted, including age appropriate vaccines and spay/neutering. The dogs are transported via a licensed carrier from Louisiana to Maine monthly.  Sorry, we do not adopt to families with children under the age of 6, or, in some instances, older depending on the breed, characteristics and/or behavior of the dog.COURTESY POSTING/REHOMING NEEDEDSeeking a loving, active person/family to adopt a sweet border collie/Australian Shepherd mix. Bandit is 7 years old. He has been with the same family his whole life. As our family grew, with a toddler and another baby on the way, Bandit is starting to need a different family life. He truly is a sweet, loving and smart dog. He needs lots of exercise. He loves to cuddle, and is good with children over the age of 10. He does have anxiety, for example he is very sensitive to clicking noises, fans, blowing noises (such as blowing out a candle). Before we had children, my now husband and I were able to train Bandit quite easily to be more tolerant of these things, but as our attention gets drawn away from his behavioral training, he does still struggle with these, and some other, daily household routine noises. He is housebroken, and gets along with other dogs (has lived with a Sheltie for most of his life without issues). He is up to date on all shots, is fixed, and has had consistent veterinary appointments. Serious inquiries only. This is a very difficult decision for us, and would love to have an “open” adoption, where we could still see Bandit on occasion, at your convenience of course.

Dodger is a 4 year old neutered male Hound mix.  He was transferred to us from an overcrowded shelter in Louisiana after being abandoned with his siblings.  Dodger is sweet, timid and gentle.  He is good with other dogs and would enjoy living with a more confident canine companion.  Dodger is timid when meeting new people.  He is NOT aggeressive and will hide until he is comfortable.  Dodger is crate trained, seems to be house trained and has nice manners.  He is still too nervous to be trusted off leash when outside so will need consistent leash walks.  Dodger walks well on a leash and likes to go for walks.  He does need a no slip collar to ensure he is safe when leashed outdoors.  Dodger has tons of potential.  He loves kids and is a gentle soul.Level: BlueWeight: 45 lbs.Adoption fee: $300

Laini is a one and a half year old spayed female Black and Tan Coonhound mix.  She was transferred to our rescue from an overcrowded shelter in LA after being surrendered by her owner.  Laini is sweet, gentle, and adorable!  She is great with other dogs and would love to have trips to the dog park to socialize with her canine friends.  She is quite physical in her play and would do well with a dog that can handle that type of interaction.  Laini is great with people, especially children.  She is crate trained, house trained and working on her manners.  She would do best crated when home alone as she tends to get into trouble when she is bored!  Laini is recovering from a skin infection that was left untreated from allergies.  She is on antibiotics and is doing great.  The vet believes that, with medicated baths and periodic rounds of antibiotics, Laini will thrive.  She may have flare ups as the seasons change.  Laini is incredibly loving and so adorable!Level: YellowWeight: 40 lbs.Adoption fee: $300

We are not sure what the mix is, so just taking a guess.  Annie gets along well with other dogs, cats and people, but she DOES NOT get along at meal time. Her savvy adopter will recognize this as not a problem, and will supervise meal times as any pet parent should do with multiple dogs at meal time. Snazzy is a 2 year old spayed female JRT mix.  She was transferred to us from an overcrowded shelter in LA after being mistreated by her owner.  Snazzy's owners were physically abusive to Snazzy and even ended up breaking her leg by throwing her.  She has healed physically and is working on healing emotionally.  Snazzy is timid with humans, and can be snappy when feeling scared, but warms up with treats and love.  She can get used to anyone but is especially nervous with men initially.  Snazzy LOVES kids and is very playful and fun with them.  She is a toy maniac and loves to play.  Snazzy is crate trained, seems to be house trained and is working on her manners.  She would benefit from a positive reinforcement training class to work on her manners and to help boost her confidence.  Snazzy is so incredibly sweet and motivated that she is eager to learn the positives of humans.  Let's help show her!Level: RedWeight: 16 lbs.Adoption fee: $300

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.wagoninn.rescuegroups.orgSamuel is a cute little mixed breed pup who needs a foster or adopter to come to NJ. Samuel was found as a stray in Louisiana. He was rescued from a shelter and is now in a foster home in Louisiana. Samuel has been vaccinated, fixed and microchipped. He is heartworm positive and will require treatment after he comes to NJ with one of our veterinarians, Barnegat Animal Clinic. Samuel is dog friendly! He is affectionate and sweet. Please consider fostering or adopting and saving a life.How to Adopt Me!If you are interested in learning more about me, and possibly making me part of your family, please go towagoninn.rescuegroups.org. Click on the orange Online Adoption Application button to fill out an application. A Wag On Inn volunteer will be in touch soon!

COURTESY POST!!!!Meet Hutch.This 4 year old stunner came to us as an abuse case from Louisiana. A “bait” dog who (now named \"Hutch\" after his finders, Tiger Hutchinson & Joanna Hutchinson) who was dumped in the middle of nowhere with a rope still hanging around his neck.Sadly, the vet determined that this sweet boy's injuries were consistent with being dragged behind a car. He had a broken jaw, was covered in wounds, was severely emaciated and was heartworm positive. Hutch's \"owners\" clearly wanted him dead. But, he had other plans. You see, Hutch refused to die. He fought to live and he's been thanking anyone involved in his recovery with tons of kisses.Hutch is ready for his forever home. He is a gorgeous, sweet big boy and loves to learn. He's been good with dogs, but we recommend a home with no cats.Will you be Hutch's hero? He deserves one.To adopt: https://goo.gl/forms/9HDOpBqgiZcC8tft1***PLEASE NOTE: HUTCH IS LOCATED IN LOUISIANA AND HIS MEDICAL WAS SPONSORED BY AARR. HE IS NOT WITH OUR RESCUE.***

Gunner's adoption fee is $400.How to Adopt Me!If you are interested in learning more about me, and possibly making me part of your family, please go towagoninn.rescuegroups.org. Mabel is a Black Lab/hound mix very pretty, and sweet. She loves to jump up and shower you with kisses. She know basic obedience, needs work on house training and leash training. She has had all shots and been treated for Heartworms. We will retest to confirm a negative. She is great with kids and other dogs once properly introduce.As Mabel was originally pulled from a shelter in Louisiana to become a PTSD service dog for veterans, and it was found that Mabel had an abundance of energy that exceeded recommended levels for PTSD dogs, so she found herself with our group. We will foster her for a time and try to find her a home. She is being fostered in a home with two Diabetic Alert Dogs and the Foster Dad suffers from severe hypoglycemia (low Blood Sugar). While she is here she sees all that is going on and has the opportunity learn and voluntarily step up and show she understands by alerting.

Melo was saved from a kill shelter in Louisiana as a puppy. Melo grew up with older children and dogs.Melo doesn't like cats. Melo is a very sweet dog.Melo deserves a family.We have a trainer who has partnered with us and Melo is in training

Baz is a catahoula leopard dog and pit mix from Louisiana. He spent most of his formative years living in a garage building or a kennel per reports. He got along with the other dogs in his foster home in Louisiana. He came with us with his sister, and the both of them love to wrestle and play for hours, so his energy level is high! He came to us earlier in the year and since then, he has learned to use a doggie door and is getting much better about housetraining. He gets along with all the dogs in his foster home, but he is fed separately because he is always hungry when he gets to eating, he snatches it up out of the bowl like he is starving. We think this is because he was never fully fed when he was growing up. He may jump on another dog while food is being given.He is very friendly and strong. He pulls on the leash, but we are getting a trainer to work with him on leash and other good behaviors. She has proven results on working with young and very good dogs like Baz. She has evaluated him and said he is an excellent dog. He would make a great search and rescue dog, dock dog or flyball pal.Anymore questions about him and the treatment he is receiving, please email sharon@blackjackrescue.org. I hope to be putting a new assessment after his first week of training.Please apply at www.blackjackrescue.org under fostering for foster to adopt or under adopting.

Angel came to us from a high kill shelter in Louisiana as part of a large shelter gone wrong case. She arrived in miserable condition, emaciated and with wounds from overcrowding and dogs competing for resources.  She is now a happy and active dog who loves life. At 4 years old and 50 pounds, Angel is a lower to medium energy girl who is perfectly content with a couple of daily walks.  Angel has mastered the art of being a very good girl.  She is fine with kids 8 and up. She has done well with other dogs, but she has to be carefully introduced.  She is likely best as an only because she seems happier that way, but she is living with dogs in her foster home. She most definitely cannot be with cats. Angel has good indoor manners, walks well on a leash and rides well in the car. She is happiest when she has enough exercise and a fenced yard to play in would be an excellent idea. She is completely happy to crash on the sofa next to you with a toy on her down time.If you would like more information on Angel,  please complete an Adoption Application at https://bigfluffydogs.com/adopt/adoption-application/ and then email nicole@bigfluffydogs.comIf you are interested in adopting this dog, please apply online, at https://bigfluffydogs.com/adopt/adoption-application/. Our main website, www.bigfluffydogs.com has more information about us and the rescue process. NOTE TO EMAILERS FROM PETFINDER: WE DO NOT RESPOND TO EMAIL INQUIRIES WITHOUT AN APPLICATION. WE REGRET WE CANNOT RESPOND TO EVERY EMAIL.We do our best to provide accurate information, but adopters must understand that each home is different and the dog may behave differently in a new home. Dogs are creatures of their environment and you help make the dog what it will be. Homes considering adopting a puppy must be prepared for: 1.) Flexible schedules for potty training. Puppies can only hold it for one hour per month of age (ex. a 4 month old puppy can only go 4 hours without a potty break). 2.) Crate training until the puppy is at least one year old, to prevent chewing on inappropriate things when you can't supervise. 3.) Socialization: The more positive and varying experiences as a puppy the better, both in and out of your home. 4.) Puppy behavior and life stages are equivalent to a human toddler. It takes at least a full year to have a calmer, well-adjusted dog. Patience is required and when your dog's behavior is a positive experience for you and those around you, your patience will be rewarded ten-fold for years to come. Please do not consider adopting a puppy if you have not thoroughly thought through the pros and cons of having one. So many people end up returning them after 3-5 months because they didn't realize the amount of work involved in raising a puppy. Patience, appropriate toys, socialization, and obedience training are all musts. All are time consuming, and can be expensive. All Dogs require supervision with children and obedience training. Adopters that want to have good dogs must be prepared to put the time and effort into training a dog. Any dog requires work and effort, but a well trained, well socialized dog is more than worth the effort put in to get them there.

Titan was just rescued from Lousiana.We think he is a catahoula leopard dog mix.He is the alpha dog of his litter, very laid back, friendly with people and dogs.5-6  months old, not sure how large he will be as he weighs 16 pounds at this point and has long legs like a deer. He loves to go to Petsmart and to the fishing pier!Also he's really looking good, putting on weight etc.  the boy loves to eat!!!!!Titan is a LOVE MACHINE and he is always ready to work!!!  He loves to play with his foster brother and sister, and gets along well with the cats.  He is great with kids.  He is super smart and working on his manners training, he can sit and come, he is highly motivated by treats.  He is super laid back and he likes to go ANYWHERE with is humans.  Somebody will be lucky to have such a wonderful boy, Please go to www.blackjackrescue.org and fill out the application for him. Under adopting!Questions email sharon@blackjackrescue.org

Treena and her sisters are a playful litter of Fox Terrier mix puppies.  Treena is slightly larger than the rest. They all love to play tug of war, chew on toys, and cuddle with their sweet Mama Lola. Treena, Twinkle, Tammy, and Tina made the long trip from Louisiana to Washington looking for forever homes. Due to the flooding in the south the shelters are full. Treena is a loving and playful puppy you need to meet!  Her DOB is 4/12/19 and she presently weighs 3.4 lbs.Puppy adoption fee is $360 plus a refundable deposit of $50 to be returned at the assigned date of spay surgery. This includes the spay or neuter surgery, age appropriate current vaccines (distemper and rabies), microchip, and preventative flea treatment.  Please stop by to see our adoptable dogs between 1pm-5pm Tuesday-Friday and 12pm-3pm on Saturdays. You are also welcome to contact us via email at emanimalhosp@aol.com. We hope to see you soon! These are rescue dogs, and we do not have any further information regarding behavior, training or past experiences. For the safety of the dogs, we need to verify residency for all adopters. Renters, please bring a copy of the lease showing that you are allowed to own a dog. Homeowners, please bring a copy of a mortgage statement proving you own your own home. We also require a copy of a utility bill with your name and address for all adopters. We encourage you to meet the pet you are applying for before submitting the application. Your application will not be approved until after you meet the pet. If you would like to print and fill out the application to bring with you to our shelter, visit our website at http://sunnyskysshelter.org/page9.html. *PLEASE NOTE - EMAILED APPLICATIONS WILL NOT BE ACCEPTED
