Please contact Jenny Cope (giveadogahome@live.com) for more information about this pet.JOSEPH was saved from a high kill shelter in Texas where dogs have just 3 dogs to be saved and transported to the rescue in Sebec, Maine. JOSEPH is neutered, core vaccines, de-wormed, monthly preventives and micro-chipped. He has an estimated date of birth of 17 February 2019 and at the time of rescue in the middle of June 2019, weighed around 30 pounds. He is listed as a Golden Retriever / German Shepherd Dog. We have no way of knowing the exact breed, it is up to individuals to decide what breed they think is most likely.Joseph was living with a foster family in Texas whilst waiting for transport and here is the great information they shared with us.The shelter named him Joshua but he never came to that. We called him Petey from the Little Rascals movie.His routine- he wakes up when we do around 5:30 am and he goes potty outside and eats his breakfast. He loves food especially TREATS! We caught him once holding his food bowl around the living room. My husband and I leave for work around 6:30 am. He stays in his crate that we bought him all morning and then my husband goes home at lunch to let him out. He goes outside and does his business. Then he gets back in his crate. We’ve had him for 6 days and the only time he had a problem with his crate was when it was raining and he didn’t go potty that morning, so he needed to get out and go. ( we put a dog camera on his house to watch him). Then we’re home by 5:00 pm and he eats dinner (we do dry food. Right now he eats Eukanuba dog brand because that’s what we feed our dogs). He plays for a little bit but really just watches my two dogs. He isn’t afraid of toys, he just acts like he doesn’t know what to do with them. We go to bed around 9:00 pm and he sleeps all night! He did sleep with us for the few days we had him. No accidents on the bed! The first two nights he woke up a few times and we let him outside to potty and then he came back to bed. He is the CUTEST sleeper! He is so long that he stretches and takes up half the bed. One night I woke up and his face was resting on my shoulder. He is so stinking cute. All he wants is love. love. love.Behavior - he knows how to sit, he learns quickly. He gives lots of kisses. He generally plays well with other dogs. I have a dachshund and it’s like he never saw a small dog before. He just followed her around and wanted to play with it. No fighting or anything. He was more curious than anything. He was more curious and observant with my two dogs, just wanted to see what was going on. I also have a mini Australian Shepherd and he wanted to play with him. Really he wanted to play with my two dogs more than they wanted to play with him. He wasn’t aggressive, no fighting.The only bad thing is that he’s a puppy still so he’s still potty training. And that’s not bad, just that he’s a puppy and still learning! He did learn to go to our back door within a couple of days! We have a doggy door and he did go through it once by himself. He had a few accidents while we had him but he’s still potty training and he knew what he did was wrong.He likes- he loves everyone!!! He’s been around my husband and I, my sister and my two grand mothers and they ALL loved him. He loves treats and giving kisses and snuggles and espionage belly rubs!! LOVES his belly rubbed. He likes bones. We gave him a puppy Nylabone and he likes to chew on that. He likes to try and play with toys. He just doesn’t know what to do with toys. He’s not scared of them, just not sure what to do. Hopefully he’ll be in a house where he’ll have all the toys in the world :). Our dogs love to play with balls, so he was slowly learning to go get it when we had him.He’ll make a great family dog!!! I don’t see him having any problems with small children. He was never around a cat, but he’d probably do the same thing he did with my mini dachshund, just kinda paw at it and try and play. He likes to lay his head on blankets and make a bed. He just wants to feel safe and comfy with lots of love.JOSEPH is available for adoption for an adoption fee of US $550Canadian adopters need to know that customs charge 15% taxes when entering into Canada. This fee is not negotiable and is used to cover the rescue costs of pulling, vetting, health certificate, transport from Texas to Maine, monthly preventatives, supplements, food and anything else that is needed.If you feel that you have the heart and home to give this precious soul a wonderful life, please go to our website, under the APPLICATION tab, complete, then submit the APPLICATION. Our process takes around 2-4 days, and ensuring your references are aware that we will be calling, could speed up the process. Once you have been approved, we discuss any questions in regards to the dog you are wanting to adopt, then you complete and submit the contract, make payment and then we can work out the pick up / transport arrangements.Please do NOT submit an application if you are not looking to take home a new best friend within the next few weeks.http://www.giveadogahome-sanantonio.orgALL Dogs are LOCATED AT THE RESCUE IN SEBEC, MAINE. We post in various states along the east coast and Canada where we have had lots of successful adoptions to enable more exposure for these beautiful saved souls. Families will need to be prepared to travel to the rescue to meet and take home their new best friend. Sebec is located just outside the towns of Dover-Foxcroft and Milo (approx 8 miles) and approx 45 miles from Bangor. There are also lots of hotels, motels, pet friendly accommodations and wonderful camp-sites for the more adventurous families and what a great way to get to know your new best friend. If there are options to arrange transport, we will work with you to make it happen.Give a Dog a Home, German Shepherd Dog Rescue187 Downs Road, Sebec, Maine, 04481giveadogahome@live.comAll pets adopted will be spay/neutered, micro-chipped, de-wormed,heartworm tested, rabies and relevant vaccinations.NO DOG WILL BE ADOPTED TO BE AN OUTSIDE DOG!If you would like to start the adoption our process is below:Submit Application with two personal references and a vet reference.If you have never had pets and do not have a vet, we will need THREE personal references.Ensure references are people who know you and your lifestyle well.Applicant MUST inform vet and references that someone from GaDaH will be calling.As long as we are able to contact your vet and references, it takes just 1-3 days to process and hopefully approve applications.If you rent we will need an approval letter for the breed of dog you are wanting to adopt from your landlord on official letterhead paper or email.Rescue processes and hopefully approves applications.Once approved, rescue invites applicant to come to the rescue to meet your chosen dog/s, spend time with him/herand then hopefully take him/her home.We do NOT hold dogs so if you are unable to come within a week or so of submitting your application the dog will still be available for adoption to other families.For Canadian adopters, all that is needed to get them across the border into Canada is a current rabies certificate and proof of adoption, which is the adoption contract. Both of which are included in the medical file you will get when you adopt. (https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/pet-travel/by-country/pettravel-canada)Ensure ALL Fields are filled in, if something is relevant, then put n/a or something in so it recognizes an entry.We do not recommend using a phone or ipad since these applications for some reason don't tend to come through and you will have spent a lot of time on the application for nothing as it will need to be re-done.Once we have you approved we can schedule an appointment for you to come to meethim/her at the rescue in Sebec, Mane and then hopefully take them home to start your new life.I just have to work on an appointment basis as I run a boarding/day care business and the rescue and so am really busy, but by planning ahead of time I can be pretty flexible.http://www.giveadogahome-sanantonio.org/adoption-application.htmlSubmit Application with two personal references and a vet reference.If you have never had pets and do not have a vet, we will need THREE personal references.Ensure references are people who know you and your lifestyle well.Applicant MUST inform vet and references that someone from GaDaH will be calling.As long as we are able to contact your vet and references, it takes just 1-3 days to process and hopefully approve applications.If you rent we will need an approval letter for the breed of dog you are wanting to adopt from your landlord on official letterhead paper or email.Rescue processes and hopefully approves applications.Once approved, rescue invites applicant to come to the rescue to meet your chosen dog/s, spend time with him/herand then hopefully take him/her home.We do NOT hold dogs so if you are unable to come within a week or so of submitting your application the dog will still be available for adoption to other families.For Canadian adopters, all that is needed to get them across the border into Canada is a current rabies certificate and proof of adoption, which is the adoption contract. Both of which are included in the medical file you will get when you adopt. (https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/pet-travel/by-count

This fee is not negotiable and is used to cover the rescue costs of pulling, vetting, health certificate, transport from Texas to Maine, monthly preventatives, supplements, food and anything else that is needed.If you feel that you have the heart and home to give this precious soul a wonderful life, please go to our website, under the APPLICATION tab, complete, then submit the APPLICATION. Our process takes around 2-4 days, and ensuring your references are aware that we will be calling, could speed up the process. Once you have been approved, we discuss any questions in regards to the dog you are wanting to adopt, then you complete and submit the contract, make payment and then we can work out the pick up / transport arrangements.Please do NOT submit an application if you are not looking to take home a new best friend within the next few weeks.http://www.giveadogahome-sanantonio.orgALL Dogs are LOCATED AT THE RESCUE IN SEBEC, MAINE. We post in various states along the east coast and Canada where we have had lots of successful adoptions to enable more exposure for these beautiful saved souls. Families will need to be prepared to travel to the rescue to meet and take home their new best friend. Sebec is located just outside the towns of Dover-Foxcroft and Milo (approx 8 miles) and approx 45 miles from Bangor. There are also lots of hotels, motels, pet friendly accommodations and wonderful camp-sites for the more adventurous families and what a great way to get to know your new best friend. If there are options to arrange transport, we will work with you to make it happen.Give a Dog a Home, German Shepherd Dog Rescue187 Downs Road, Sebec, Maine, 04481giveadogahome@live.comAll pets adopted will be spay/neutered, micro-chipped, de-wormed,heartworm tested, rabies and relevant vaccinations.NO DOG WILL BE ADOPTED TO BE AN OUTSIDE DOG!If you would like to start the adoption our process is below:Submit Application with two personal references and a vet reference.If you have never had pets and do not have a vet, we will need THREE personal references.Ensure references are people who know you and your lifestyle well.Applicant MUST inform vet and references that someone from GaDaH will be calling.As long as we are able to contact your vet and references, it takes just 1-3 days to process and hopefully approve applications.If you rent we will need an approval letter for the breed of dog you are wanting to adopt from your landlord on official letterhead paper or email.Rescue processes and hopefully approves applications.Once approved, rescue invites applicant to come to the rescue to meet your chosen dog/s, spend time with him/herand then hopefully take him/her home.We do NOT hold dogs so if you are unable to come within a week or so of submitting your application the dog will still be available for adoption to other families.For Canadian adopters, all that is needed to get them across the border into Canada is a current rabies certificate and proof of adoption, which is the adoption contract. Both of which are included in the medical file you will get when you adopt. (https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/pet-travel/by-country/pettravel-canada)Ensure ALL Fields are filled in, if something is relevant, then put n/a or something in so it recognizes an entry.We do not recommend using a phone or ipad since these applications for some reason don't tend to come through and you will have spent a lot of time on the application for nothing as it will need to be re-done.Once we have you approved we can schedule an appointment for you to come to meethim/her at the rescue in Sebec, Mane and then hopefully take them home to start your new life.I just have to work on an appointment basis as I run a boarding/day care business and the rescue and so am really busy, but by planning ahead of time I can be pretty flexible.http://www.giveadogahome-sanantonio.org/adoption-application.htmlSubmit Application with two personal references and a vet reference.If you have never had pets and do not have a vet, we will need THREE personal references.Ensure references are people who know you and your lifestyle well.Applicant MUST inform vet and references that someone from GaDaH will be calling.As long as we are able to contact your vet and references, it takes just 1-3 days to process and hopefully approve applications.If you rent we will need an approval letter for the breed of dog you are wanting to adopt from your landlord on official letterhead paper or email.Rescue processes and hopefully approves applications.Once approved, rescue invites applicant to come to the rescue to meet your chosen dog/s, spend time with him/herand then hopefully take him/her home.We do NOT hold dogs so if you are unable to come within a week or so of submitting your application the dog will still be available for adoption to other families.For Canadian adopters, all that is needed to get them across the border into Canada is a current rabies certificate and proof of adoption, which is the adoption contract. She is full of life, energy and love and would make a great family addition. She has been loving to all who have met her and the vets office fell in love with her when she went for her spay surgery. As with all dogs basic obedience and general training is needed so that she can learn the new rules, boundaries and expectations of her new family and home.I do not know how ELSA would be around cats or livestock.She rides great in the car, walks great on the leash, is great with other dogs and people of all ages, she uses the dog door to get in and out to play or to do her business but she won't know to let her new family know she needs to go out, so a few accidents whilst she goes through this big transition should be expected and then if there are not any, it is a bonus :)All dogs (except dogs saved from China) are available for adoption for an adoption fee of $550.Canadian adopters need to know that customs charge 15% taxes when entering into Canada. Please contact Jenny Cope (giveadogahome@live.com) for more information about this pet.CHIP-L was saved from a high kill shelter in Texas with his 3 buddies, all feral and had been scheduled to be killed the day we saved them. CHIP-L is neutered, core vaccines, rabies, heartworm and tick disease tested negative, monthly preventatives and microchipped. He has an estimated date of birth of 20 April 2016 and at the time of rescue in May 2018 weighed around 11 pounds.CHIP, PRINCE, MILO & PIXIE were all saved together. When I had informed the shelter I would take them into rescue, they informed me they were scheduled to be killed that day because they were feral. I had committed to them and so I couldn't back out.When they got here I let them with the other dogs and just left them to it as I think it is important for dogs to decompress and figure out what has happened to them the last week, being picked up by animal control, taken to a large city kill shelter, having surgery and all the vetting then on a transport up to the rescue for 3 days, then getting here - it is so much for them all in such a short time.CHIP has come a very long way and will come and sit next to me, he will let me scratch his head, belly, he will play although he does \"mouth\" when playing. He gets very excited when playing and is a very sweet boy. I let him build his confidence on his own and come up to me when he felt ready. At first it was taking treats and then this slowly progressed to me scratching his chest and ears, then eventually his belly. He is truly desperate for affection and he wants nothing more than to cuddle up on my lap. At times he has sneaked on the chair next to me and gone to sleep, however, he will not let me pick up he will run off, but then immediately come back.As you can see in the video he does want to play, but he does \"mouth\" when playing and at times can put a bit too much pressure, he is not biting he just doesn't know he is playing too hard, but I gently correct him, telling him no and he does stop. This will take time, but the fact he has come so far on his own, in his own time, I believe with the right family he has huge potential.CHIP needs a family that understands he is going to need time to figure things out again and do things at his own pace. He isn't going to be jumping on your lap snuggling up straight away, he isn't going to let you pick him up or take him for walks for a considerable time so a fenced in yard is an absolute must. With time, love and patience everything can come, being with a family that has time to spend with him, teaching him things and helping him gain trust will enable him to develop the confidence and trust he needs.We do not recommend children more because of his mouthing little hard and also children are not as patient in allowing him to progress at his own pace.CHIP truly is a very sweet boy, he enjoys the other dogs, he enjoys sitting on the back of the sofa watching the squirrels and birds at the feeding stations. He loves to get attention and deserves the best family and forever home.We do not have cats or livestock at the rescue so cannot comment on how he would be around or with them.All dogs (except dogs saved from China) are available for adoption for an adoption fee of $550.Canadian adopters need to know that customs charge 15% taxes when entering into Canada. This fee is not negotiable and is used to cover the rescue costs of pulling, vetting, health certificate, transport from Texas to Maine, monthly preventatives, supplements, food and anything else that is needed.If you feel that you have the heart and home to give this precious soul a wonderful life, please go to our website, under the APPLICATION tab, complete, then submit the APPLICATION. Our process takes around 2-4 days, and ensuring your references are aware that we will be calling, could speed up the process. Once you have been approved, we discuss any questions in regards to the dog you are wanting to adopt, then you complete and submit the contract, make payment and then we can work out the pick up / transport arrangements.Please do NOT submit an application if you are not looking to take home a new best friend within the next few weeks.http://www.giveadogahome-sanantonio.orgALL Dogs are LOCATED AT THE RESCUE IN SEBEC, MAINE.We post in various states along the east coast and Canada where we have had lots of successful adoptions to enable more exposure for these beautiful saved souls. Families will need to be prepared to travel to the rescue to meet and take home their new best friend. Sebec is located just outside the towns of Dover-Foxcroft and Milo (approx 8 miles) and approx 45 miles from Bangor. There are also lots of hotels, motels, pet friendly accommodations and wonderful camp-sites for the more adventurous families and what a great way to get to know your new best friend. If there are options to arrange transport, we will work with you to make it happen.Give a Dog a Home, German Shepherd Dog Rescue187 Downs Road, Sebec, Maine, 04481giveadogahome@live.comAll pets adopted will be spay/neutered, micro-chipped, de-wormed,heartworm tested, rabies and relevant vaccinations.NO DOG WILL BE ADOPTED TO BE AN OUTSIDE DOG!If you would like to start the adoption our process is below:Submit Application with two personal references and a vet reference.If you have never had pets and do not have a vet, we will need THREE personal references.Ensure references are people who know you and your lifestyle well.Applicant MUST inform vet and references that someone from GaDaH will be calling.As long as we are able to contact your vet and references, it takes just 1-3 days to process and hopefully approve applications.If you rent we will need an approval letter for the breed of dog you are wanting to adopt from your landlord on official letterhead paper or email.Rescue processes and hopefully approves applications.Once approved, rescue invites applicant to come to the rescue to meet your chosen dog/s, spend time with him/herand then hopefully take him/her home.We do NOT hold dogs so if you are unable to come within a week or so of submitting your application the dog will still be available for adoption to other families.For Canadian adopters, all that is needed to get them across the border into Canada is a current rabies certificate and proof of adoption, which is the adoption contract. Both of which are included in the medical file you will get when you adopt. (https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/pet-travel/by-country/pettravel-canada)Ensure ALL Fields are filled in, if something is relevant, then put n/a or something in so it recognizes an entry.We do not recommend using a phone or ipad since these applications for some reason don't tend to come through and you will have spent a lot of time on the application for nothing as it will need to be re-done.Once we have you approved we can schedule an appointment for you to come to meethim/her at the rescue in Sebec, Mane and then hopefully take them home to start your new life.I just have to work on an appointment basis as I run a boarding/day care business and the rescue and so am really busy, but by planning ahead of time I can be pretty flexible.http://www.giveadogahome-sanantonio.org/adoption-application.htmlSubmit Application with two personal references and a vet reference.If you have never had pets and do not have a vet, we will need THREE personal references.Ensure references are people who know you and your lifestyle well.Applicant MUST inform vet and references that someone from GaDaH will be calling.As long as we are able to contact your vet and references, it takes just 1-3 days to process and hopefully approve applications.If you rent we will need an approval letter for the breed of dog you are wanting to adopt from your landlord on official letterhead paper or email.Rescue processes and hopefully approves applications.Once approved, rescue invites applicant to come to the rescue to meet your chosen dog/s, spend time with him/herand then hopefully take him/her home.We do NOT hold dogs so if you are unable to come within a week or so of submitting your application the dog will still be available for adoption to other families.For Canadian adopters, all that is needed to get them across the border into Canada is a current rabies certificate and proof of adoption, which is the adoption contract. Please contact Jenny Cope (giveadogahome@live.com) for more information about this pet.NOEL was saved from a high kill shelter in Texas where dogs have just 3 dogs to be saved. NOEL is spayed, core vaccines, rabies, de-wormed, monthly preventatives and micro-chipped. She has an estimated date of birth of 6 December 2018 and at the time of rescue in the middle of April 2019, weighed around 29.60 pounds. She is listed as a Lab Mix . We have no way of knowing the exact breed, it is up to individuals to decide what breed they think is most likely.We do not have cats or livestock at the rescue so are unable to comment how any dog is or will be around them. NOEL is a young, high energy, fun loving girl. She loves everyone she meets and is fantastic with other dogs. She loves to chase and be chased and will play and wrestle with the other dogs and then relax and sleep cuddled up amongst them. She can be vocal when she is playing and does instigate play, and is great with both small, medium and large dogs.She would be a great family pet, she is so much fun, so loving and gentle. She is always friendly and happy to see me or the volunteers that come occasionally come over.As with all dogs she will need basic and advanced training so that so she can learn her families rules, boundaries and expectations. NOEL is very responsive and I feel that she will be easy and fun to train and will be eager to please. She is a gentle girl and I think would make a great family dog.NOEL would be great in a family environment but she must understand that she is not in charge and that rules and boundaries must be followed, she is confident and so I am sure she would push and test the boundaries. She is young, fun and would be great for an active family to take her on long walks and adventures.All dogs (except dogs saved from China) are available for adoption for an adoption fee of US $550.Canadian adopters need to know that customs charge 15% taxes when entering into Canada. Please contact Jenny Cope (giveadogahome@live.com) for more information about this pet.TINKERBELL was saved from a high kill shelter in Texas where dogs have just 3 dogs to be saved. TINKERBELL is spayed, core vaccines, rabies, de-wormed, heartworm and tick disease tested negative and micro-chipped. She has an estimated date of birth of 3 December 2015 and at the time of rescue at the beginning of December 2018 weighed around 17.60 pounds. She is listed as a Yorkshire Terrier / Cairn Terrier Mix. We have no way of knowing the exact breed, it is up to individuals to decide what breed they think is most likely.TINKERBELL IS NOT GOOD WITH CATS.TINKERBELL was adopted at the end of December 2018 but was returned to the rescue in February 2019 due to her having prey drive for the families cats. They tried to make it work, but were concerned for both the cats well-being and also of Tinkerbell and so with sad hearts they brought her back. They said she was very active and would need a family that does go on walks and adventures and gives here the opportunity to run a lot. They was training her to stand on her back feet for treats and had a lot of fun with her. After a few days the family reached back out stating that they are going to build a place for the cats as they want her back in their lives, so they came and picked her back up. Sadly this only lasted for a few months since Tinkerbell continued to be aggressive with the cats.In March Tinkerbell had 3 seizures within the month and the vet prescribed prednisone. No cause has been diagnosed and she has been doing great, but this is of course a consideration for families when they consider adopting her as she may need life-long medications, which prednisone is very in-expensive, but since she stll has a lot of life in her, regular testing would be recommended.When Tinkerbell arrived at the rescue in December she was very shy and a little over-whelmed with all the other dogs. After a few days she settled down and got into the routine, although she was still reserved and didn't like being with a lot of dogs. When in a smaller groups she was fine. She has never been aggressive with other dogs or protective over food or anything else whilst here at the rescue. She rides great in the car and loves to snuggle.As with all rescue's she needs guidance and training and we recommend families go through at least the basics of training with her themselves so that boundaries, personalities and body language can be learned from each other. TINKERBELL is very responsive and training would be fun and easy as long as proper training techniques are followed and are consistent.Although Tinkerbell is a small dog, she is an active girl and walks, runs and adventures is important for her to live a fulfilled life.We do not recommend dog parks for several weeks, if not months, it is so very important for families and dogs to form a strong bond and get to know each other before exposing them to the potential dangers of dog parks. Although all GaDaH dogs are very well socialized with other dogs, lots of other dogs have not had the benefit of this socialization and do not always know how to play and act with other dogs. You also do not know the control the other families have over their dogs and you should always have a good recall for your adopted dog before going to dog parks.All dogs (except dogs saved from China) are available for adoption for an adoption fee of $550.Canadian adopters need to know that customs charge 15% taxes when entering into Canada. This fee is not negotiable and is used to cover the rescue costs of pulling, vetting, health certificate, transport from Texas to Maine, monthly preventatives, supplements, food and anything else that is needed.If you feel that you have the heart and home to give this precious soul a wonderful life, please go to our website, under the APPLICATION tab, complete, then submit the APPLICATION. Families will need to be prepared to travel to the rescue to meet and take home their new best friend. Sebec is located just outside the towns of Dover-Foxcroft and Milo (approx 8 miles) and approx 45 miles from Bangor. There are also lots of hotels, motels, pet friendly accommodations and wonderful camp-sites for the more adventurous families and what a great way to get to know your new best friend. Please contact Jenny Cope (giveadogahome@live.com) for more information about this pet.IMPORTANT - READ ALL INFORMATION PROVIDEDTILLY was saved from a high kill shelter in Texas in May 2018, where dogs generally have just 3 days to be saved before they are killed for space. TILLY is spayed, core vaccines, rabies, de-wormed, heartworm tested negative and micro-chipped. She has an estimated date of birth of 18 April 2010 and weighs around 14.20 pounds. She has been listed as a Cairn Terrier Fox Terrier Mix. We have no way of knowing the exact breed, so it is up to individuals to decide what breed they think is most likely.At the beginning of June 2018, Tilly was adopted and went to start her new life. Unfortunately in the middle of March 2019 I received an email from the family saying that she would need to be returned to the rescue. The problems the family had was that Tilly had started to get protective of her chair, and her home, she would bark and growl at people coming into the home. The family took her to the vet who recommended a training program and then anxiety medications. Tilly's negative behaviour continued and the family again reached out to the vet wanting her taken off the medication as there had been no significant improvement, the vet, even knowing that the rescue would take her back offered euthanasia as an option. Tilly had not bitten anyone and she had not a recent physical exam or blood panel done to rule out any medical issues for her personality change. Thankfully the family brought her back to the rescue.When TILLY first got back to the rescue I noticed how over-weight she was. I put her in the bedroom which is off the main living area where there is a gate installed so she could come out of her crate and get to know the dogs and start to decompress slowly. She was at first growly with me which I tolerated for the first day back, on day two I shouted at her, pointing and telling her \"no, this behaviour was not acceptable\". I sat on the floor and within minutes she came belly-crawling over and turned over next to me to let me scratch her belly. That has been the extent of her aggression.After a few days I let her out into the main living area with the 20 other dogs of all ages and sizes and she was a little over-whelmed, she had places she could go to have her own space which she did do mostly for the first week. She was very needy in that she would want to jump up on my knee and followed me around, which was to be expected since that was what she was used to with her family and also I am sure she wanted to be near me for a bit of security. I didn't allow this as it is important to know that she is not going to dictate the rules, that she is a member of the family, but is not in charge. At the time of writing this Tilly has been back at the rescue for 2 weeks and she has been doing great, she has growled at the other dogs, but only for them to get out of her space, she instigated play with one of the smaller dogs and is definitely coming out of her shell and getting a lot more confidence in walking around.The rescue has had her to the vet to have blood drawn and a full CBCand 27 Chemistry panel including testing for thyroid issues so that we can rule out hypothyroidism, some symptoms are weight gain and sudden aggression. Her extensive blood and chemistry panel came back good with nothing of any concern. She had a vets appointment on 9th April and had an examination that went well and it was agreed from the information and medical assessment that this is more of a behaviour issue and she just needs a family that will not let her get away with things, which will encourage negative behaviour. We think it was more that she was allowed to become \"alpha\" of the home and family, which led to her being territorial and consequently aggressive. The good thing is that there are no medical issues that we need to worry about.TILLY is going to need a family that understands that she has exhibited negative behaviour and is confident and comfortable in giving a negative consequence to a negative behaviour, like you would do with children or any human for that matter. Her family said she absolutely loved going for walks and car rides and was a really happy go lucky girl although a little timid at times and they truly was heartbroken how things developed but did the right thing in bringing her back since they was not able to deal with her behaviour.Rescue Bio before TILLY was returned.TILLY doens't act 8 years old, she is pretty active, very playful, she is great with other dogs, but not too bothered in playing with them all the time, she likes to follow me around and will get a silly mood and spin around when I go over to feed and clean. She has a mischievous streak in she was trying to pull the to the other side of the fence she was on and started pulling it apart. She loves to have mad dashes and spins around in her crazy moments.We do not have cats or livestock at the rescue, so we cannot comment on how she would respond or act with or around them.A volunteer brought her young granddaughter over and she was great with her, initially she was a little bit shy, but soon warmed up and very loving and wanting to get lots of attention.TILLY does use the dog door to go out to do her business. I do not know if she would let you know she needs to go out since she has 24/7 access to the outside, so it is important to note she will most likely need some training.She is going to need a family that is used to small dogs. Someone who understand that he will need training and guidance and learns that humans are in charge so that he doesn't get too much of a handful. A somewhat active family who can give him the lifestyle that she needs. Going on road trips, to new places, hikes and adventures and letting her explore the sights, smells and sounds the world has to offer will be to his and your benefit. We do not recommend dog parks for several weeks, if not months, it is so very important for families and dogs to form a strong bond and get to know each other before exposing them to the potential dangers of dog parks. Although all GaDaH dogs are very well socialized with other dogs, lots of other dogs have not had the benefit of this socialization and do not always know how to play and act with other dogs. You also do not know the control the other families have over their dogs and you should always have a good recall for your adopted dog before going to dog parks.TILLY is available for adoption for an adoption fee of $550. Canadian adopters need to know that customs charge 15% taxes when entering into Canada.This fee is not negotiable and is used to cover the rescue costs of pulling, vetting, health certificate, transport from Texas to Maine, monthly preventatives, supplements, food and anything else that is needed.If you feel that you have the heart and home to give this precious soul a wonderful life, please go to our website, under the APPLICATION tab, complete, then submit the APPLICATION. Our process takes around 2-4 days, and ensuring your references are aware that we will be calling, could speed up the process. Once you have been approved, we discuss any questions in regards to the dog you are wanting to adopt, then you complete and submit the contract, make payment and then we can work out the pick up / transport arrangements.Please do NOT submit an application if you are not looking to take home a new best friend within the next few weeks.http://www.giveadogahome-sanantonio.orgTILLY is LOCATED AT THE RESCUE IN SEBEC, MAINE. We post in various states along the east coast and Canada where we have had lots of successful adoptions to enable more exposure for these beautiful saved souls. Families will need to be prepared to travel to the rescue to meet and take home their new best friend. Sebec is located just outside the towns of Dover-Foxcroft and Milo (approx 8 miles) and approx 45 miles from Bangor. There are also lots of hotels, motels, pet friendly accommodations and wonderful camp-sites for the more adventurous families and what a great way to get to know your new best friend. Give a Dog a Home, German Shepherd Dog Rescue187 Downs Road, Sebec, Maine, 04481giveadogahome@live.comAll pets adopted will be spay/neutered, micro-chipped, de-wormed,heartworm tested, rabies and relevant vaccinations.NO DOG WILL BE ADOPTED TO BE AN OUTSIDE DOG!If you would like to start the adoption our process is below:Submit Application with two personal references and a vet reference.If you have never had pets and do not have a vet, we will need THREE personal references.Ensure references are people who know you and your lifestyle well.Applicant MUST inform vet and references that someone from GaDaH will be calling.As long as we are able to contact your vet and references, it takes just 1-3 days to process and hopefully approve applications.If you rent we will need an approval letter for the breed of dog you are wanting to adopt from your landlord on official letterhead paper or email.Rescue processes and hopefully approves applications.Once approved, rescue invites applicant to come to the rescue to meet your chosen dog/s, spend time with him/herand then hopefully take him/her home.We do NOT hold dogs so if you are unable to come within a week or so of submitting your application the dog will still be available for adoption to other families.For Canadian adopters, all that is needed to get them across the border into Canada is a current rabies certificate and proof of adoption, which is the adoption contrac

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.I was rescued from a high kill shelter in Texas. I arrived to my foster in Virginia on June 15th. I am currently living with my foster family in Sterling, VA which includes 4 humans (a mom, a dad, a young adult, and a teen) along with 3 other furkids (large, medium, and small).I am really enjoying getting to know them and they are all teaching me what the rules are and treating me like one of the family. My favorite things to do are to play catch and practice my howling with the teen, play with the other pups, well the ones that like to play (there's an old gal who has let me know that my youthful energy is not appreciated), and chill with the pack. She also takes me on walks (I'm still learning how to walk with that long stringy thing) and runs with me in the yard. When we are done, she spends time with me on the floor rubbing my belly or scratching my ears ( I REALLY love that part).Sometimes during the day I just like to chill in one of my crates or on the floor. They have lots of cushy stuff to lay on so it's comfortable and I like having my own space at times.I'm minding my P's and Q's and eating nicely and not making a mess when I drink water. I'm looking for a furever home with a loving family who is patient so I can learn things. I would be great on my own or with other dogs, but I like an active life. I really like these older kids, but it would be great to meet some smaller ones to see if I like them too. I heard there are these other creatures called cats, but I haven't met one yet to see if I like them or if they like me. I'm gonna let my foster mom take it from here to tell you a little more about me. (she likes to brag)Hiya, Shana's Foster Mom here. From the moment my husband saw Shana's eyes he knew we needed to pull her from the kill shelter. She has fit in with our pack so easily and very quickly. She was originally quiet on the ride home, but once in the house became more verbal. She was spayed on day three of having her and is healing nicely. She knows a few basic commands like sit, crate and is learning stay. She has not shown any signs of food aggression and is highly food motivated when training. You can see the intelligence in her eyes when you are teaching her. Keep in mind, she is young and has a lot of energy, but if you are active with her, she is a dream through the night.We noticed that she is most verbal when others approach her humans, thus showing a protective nature of the people she loves. When our teen leaves, she cries for her a little then goes to lay down. She sleeps in the crate with no issues and has even handled the cone of shame like a champ. (Our dogs all hated it.)Shana is definitely an alpha female and likes to be in charge. Because she is young, she has a ton of energy and would be best suited with a family that is active outdoors.We were honored to be able to name her because she was found by the dog catcher in south Texas and put in the shelter. She had a collar on with 2 feet of chain on it that she had been dragging around. They suspect her previous owners had her chained up outside when the hurricanes hit Texas and she managed to escape, but no one ever came to claim her and she was placed on the kill list.Once she was on their site, one of our SSR volunteers saw her and posted her pics. That's when my hubby saw her. Almost everyone was commenting on the post and saying how pretty she is, so I asked the SSR founders if we could name her Shana, which is \"pretty\" in Yiddish. The rest is history!We are looking for a very special family who will deserve her love because she has so much to give. If YOU are that family, please submit your application right away. We will attend as many adoption events as we can so you can meet her. If you're still with me in reading all of this, you could be the family she's looking for! Thank you.If you are an approved adopter and are interested in this dog, please let your case worker know. You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.Hi there. I'm Sheba. I was picked up as a stray in Texas in July and brought to my foster home at the end of October. I am not spayed and have never been pregnant so I was likely not a stray for very long. I am currently in heat. Once that is finished I will get spayed and then start on treatment for heartworm. I am told that my foster dad is not looking for a forever home for me until I am spayed, though.I had an interesting first 24 hours with my new foster dad. He picked me up from the nice ladies who drove me all the way from Texas to Virginia and took me straight to a place where I got a bath. I was very good for my bath and allowed him to do all the things that he had to do to get me \"clean\". I thought I was just fine the way I was but the warm water was nice. I then met the 2 owners of the house, Duke who is a German Shepherd like me and Lily who is a Border Collie mix. They smelled Ok, I guess. I did not pay too much attention to them. I then had a look around the house. While I was doing that my foster dad got some food for me which I ate really quickly. He says I am \"overly enthusiastic\" when I eat and I try to see what is on the kitchen counters a lot, but I am just really hungry and it is hard to get over not knowing when your next meal will be. I slept in a crate all night and was so tired, I did not fuss at all.I then went for a walk around the block. It was a nice walk and I just followed my foster dad. I don't usually pull on the leash but sometimes when I see a squirrel or fox or deer I want to chase them. I don't try too hard to do that because my leash and collar stop me and I don't want to pull too hard.In the morning I went to the vet. That is when we figured out I was in heat. I was very good for the doctor and let her do all the things she needed to. I did not complain at all.I sometimes chase my tail and chew on it. I also have a bit of a hotspot on my back but that is clearing up. We are going to ask about my tail, though. I have chewed through much of the hair there.I always like to be with my foster dad but sometimes he puts me in a crate. That is ok but I don't like it when I hear him but can't be with him. I try and jump around in my crate and make noises so he will come get me out. If he does not then I will stop after 5 minutes or so. I am good with being in my crate at night and when he goes out, though.I understand a few of the words dad uses to ask me to do things. I know sit, stay (although for these I usually will expect a treat at some point), and come. There are others but he has not figured them out and I am surely not going to tell him what they are. Gotta make him work for it. I have gotten along well with my foster brother and sister so far. I have met dogs when we walk and they have seemed nice. I am not sure how I feel about cats but if they run I will chase them so dad does not think I would be good with them.A couple of days after I got to Virginia there was something called Halloween. Not sure what that was but dad and I sat outside while a bunch of strange small people came up to the house. Dad said I was very well behaved and I let a lot of them pet me. There were some really small ones, too.My foster dad tells me I am nice to have around and once I figure out that I will never have to worry about eating so I am not so enthusiastic about my food (and treats) and stop counter surfing, I will be a really awesome family member.If you want to see more about my day to day progress, click this link https://trello.com/b/ce6g2fmk. It will take you a web page called \"Trello\" where you can read more about me and see pictures.If you want to contact my foster dad about me, he gave me my own email address. It is sheba@ennoil.comIf you are an approved adopter and are interested in this dog, please let your case worker know. You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.Joy came to us from Texas and we all know that everything is bigger in Texas and and so is her personality.- Joy is a very, very happy dog.- She is super sweet and loves to cuddle (all the time if you let her).- Joy gets along well with all people, young and old and greets everybody like a long lost friend. - She is house and crate trained.- Joy loves going on walks and car rides and knows basic commands. - Joy is very dominant with other dogs and we therefore recommend that she is the only dog in the family.Joy would like to have a future home with few steps to go outside, a ranch style house would be perfect for her. She is doing very well on three legs but too many stairs are difficult for her.Joy is in excellent health, but tires easily because of having only three legs. She enjoys short, slow paced walks with a lot of breaks. She is the perfect companion for people watching or sitting in a field enjoying nature.She would love to have a family that has time to spend with her during the day. She would do well as a companion for a retired couple or someone working from home since she does not require a lot of exercise.

Duke is a 10 year old Shepard Mix. We are pretty sure he was named after royalty since there isn’t anything about this boy that’s very tough. Originally from Texas, this southern gentleman made his way to Maine by a transport.  He is a super friendly boy that is pretty indifferent to other dogs. He seems much more interested in saying hello to people as he passes by on his way to and from his kennel. He will make a wonderful family member and is looking forward to meeting any dog or kid siblings. He has no cat history but with proper introductions would most likely,  be fine. He is looking for some  belly rubs, snuggle time, and people to meet and greet  PLEASE NOTE - We will check your veterinary reference, to ensure that current and prior pets have a history of being kept up to date on vaccines, annual exams and recommended bloodwork. We also do home checks to make sure that your home environment meets the needs of the particular dog you are interested in.If you’re interested in adoption, please fill out our online adoption survey at http://olddogsnewdigs.com/form-adoption.html.

Abby is a 1 year old female lab mix who came from our most recent transport from Lubbock, Texas! This beautiful girl is very sweet, smart, and playful! Abby would do best in a home with children 12 or older. She doesn't know much just yet other than sit but she is very food motivated and very willing to learn! Ideally Abby would enjoy a family all to herself, but may do well with a tolerant doggy friend. She's proven to be a wonderful hiking companion and A+ cuddler once tired. Come meet this sweet girl today!

Duncan is a 5 month old lab mix who came to us from our most Texas transport! Duncan is a very active, playful, and outgoing guy! He would lvoe a home with children 10 +, and someone who he can play with daily! Come meet this playful guy today!

Batman is a 1 year old male lab mix who came to us from our very first transport from Lubbock, Texas!! This handsome guy can be shy at first but warms up quickly and is so, SO goofy and loving! His lanky legs and endless butt wiggles are truly a sight to behold. He currently knows sit, and is very food motivated so training should go well. Batman would do best in a home with children 12 or older and potentially another doggy friend. Come meet this handsome guy today!

Sadie is a 10 month old cattle dog mix with absolutely stunning tick markings. She is one of the very first dogs to be transported to our shelter from Lubbock, Texas! She is a very loving and curious little girl that would enjoy hiking the 603, chilling out on the couch, or playing fetch in the yard. Sadie's a wonderful dog all around, but she would do best in an active home with teens or older, and would absolutely love another dog in the household.

How is this kangaroo in a shelter?! Cheerio is a 4 year old chihuahua mix who came to us from our most recent Texas transport! Cheerio is definitely a busy body and would love a fun and playful home.  He would do best in a home with children 8 and up and seems to do well with other dogs. He might chase cats, but Cheerio is pretty much cat sized himself and can certainly be trained to be good around the, Come by to meet him!

Hi! My name is Marshall.  People call me a handsome bullmatian from Fort Worth, TX. My foster mom pulled me from the really scary shelter and moved me all the way to New Hampshire! She tells me I’m a really good boy, but the first two years and eight months of my life weren’t easy. The scary shelter guys found me on the streets, then I spent four months in a loud, dirty puppy jail known as the shelter.This was a scary place for me and being behind bars made me terrified of people.  They would walk by, stare in my kennel, I would cower and growl to prevent them from coming in, not realizing I was losing any chance I had in finding a home.  After four months, my time was up and on that last day my foster mom saw me and for whatever her reason was, she picked me!  That was my lucky day to break free of jail!   I had no idea my life was about to get better!My foster mom is kind, gentle and patient and within a few days I was able to shake off the shelter blues and start learning how to trust, love and be loved again.  It’s been a slow process, but a steady one and I’m enjoying being loyal canine companion!Naturally, I’m still working on confidence and trust and I’m still a little afraid of crates, but I’m trying to work past all that.  It sometimes takes me a while to warm up to humans, but if they give me time and space, I will gently engage when I’m ready.  Some of my favorite activities are walking, cuddling and playing with my toys!  I have wonderful leash skills and I have to say I’m pretty athletic too!  My foster mom is teaching me new tricks like sit and stay and I’m eager to learn even more!   I’m really good with the “drop” word too, probably because I think some of my foster mom’s things are toys and she uses that word a lot, especially when I take her pillows.I’m okay with other dogs as long as they are respectful.  Puppies and high energy dogs make me nervous so I would prefer a home where I can get all of the attention to myself, or one with another low-key, mellow canine friend.   I’ve never met a kitty face to face, but I don’t care to chase the strays in the neighborhood.  Being with my foster mom is way better than chasing any kitties.My ideal home would be with adults who like to enjoy the outdoors.  A family that has routine, likes to be with their canine companion, continue to teach new skills and confidence, one with patience and understanding and one that will enjoy watching my wings spread.   I am looking forward to putting my past behind me and look forward to a future and a family.

Saint is 50 lbs of cuteness! He's about 3 years old and we believe he's a Terrier mix.We recently saved Saint minutes from death in a high kill shelter in Texas. He unfortunately does not get along with other dogs. He will have to be the only dog in the home. He's learning commands like \"sit\" and \"stay\". He will benefit from future training to keep him stimulated and entertained.Unfortunately Donald doesn't do well with small children or other dogs. He is 60 lbs and about 2 years old. Maria is a shy but sweet Shepherd/Rottweiler mix. She is bonded with her buddy Polo, who were both saved minutes from death from a high kill shelter in Texas. Maria is super playful and gets along with other dogs. Her favorite dog to play with? Polo!! Unfortunately Polo has been adopted, leaving Maria to wait for her forever home.Maria is currently in Texas, but she can be transported to an approved adopter!Maria is 40 lbs and about 2 years old.If you're interested in adopting Maria, please fill out an adoption application on our website: www.safetails.orgIf you have any questions on Maria, please feel free to message us via our rescue's Facebook page!

Crystal is a really sweet girl that needs someone to show her that she still matters! She was recently saved from a high kill shelter in San Antonio, Texas, where she was abandoned by her owners. Unfortunately, Crystal doesn't do too well with other dogs right now. She's very fearful and growls when another dog tries to approach her. She's being worked with and will hopefully come around, but as of now she will have to be the only dog in the home. Crystal is 50 lbs and about 2.5 years old. She is currently in Texas, but can be transported to an approved adopter. This girl is ready to get all the TLC and love that she deserves!If you're interested in adopting Crystal, please fill out an adoption application on our website: www.safetails.org

Joey was recently saved from a high kill shelter in San Antonio, Texas so we don’t know much about him just yet. What we do know is that Joey is a sweet boy that gets along with other dogs. He weighs 45 lbs and is about 3 years old. He can’t wait for someone to love him and give him a family of his own!

Sophie is a 4 year old, 10 pound Chihuahua who was saved moments from being killed at a Texas shelter. She is shy at first but once she warms up, she is sweet and loving. She gets along with people and other dogs fairly well. She can be sassy with bigger dogs, but she still gets along with them. She would do best with older children. She has been sitting with her foster's young children and enjoying their attention, but sometimes she has had enough and gets snappy. She enjoys getting treats, playing fetch with her ball and snuggling up with her people. She does not like her collar or harness put on, and is scared of the leash, so she uses potty pads well in her foster home. She would probably do best with an experienced dog owner. Sophie is currently in Texas with her foster family but can be transported to an approved adopter. Can you give this pretty little girl the furever home she deserves?If you have any questions on Sophie, please feel free to message us via our rescue’s Facebook page!If you're interested in adopting Sophie, please fill out an adoption application on our website www.safetails.org.

TIMBER!!! Timber is a male shepherd mix with lots of puppy energy. Estimated between 4-5 month old. He hails from a Texas shelter near the Mexican border. Little else is known about his past before he was transported up here to Michigan. Working on potty training, but is a potty holder in his crate. He doesn't love the crate, but will calm down after about 10 minutes and can be left for about 4-5 hours if needed.Timber is working on learning manners, he takes treats nicely, but needs more practice of sitting, rather than jumping, to get his treat.He walks well on a leash. Timber gets along with his dog foster siblings. He likes to try to play with the resident kitty, so may do ok in a home with a cat that would be more prone to hide away than defend itself aggressively. Due to his high energy level, he will need a fenced yard and an active owner. And older, respectful children should be ok, too. He can be pretty aloof, somewhat independent, until he tires out. Then he turns into a cuddle bug. Timber likes to bring the outside indoors, like twigs and pinecones. But also enjoys chew toys and tennis balls. He's a fan of playing in his water dish and drinking from the outdoor water hose. He would make an excellent jogging or hiking partner.Timber is neutered, vaccinated, microchipped, and ready for his forever family!Timber is available for adoption through Pet Tales Rescue in Grand Rapids, MI. Please go to www.pettalesrescue.com and fill out an application. His adoption fee is $265 plus $15 for the microchip for a total of $280 payable by cash or card through the rescue's website.* Pet Tales Rescue does not have a physical shelter location as all of our pets are in foster homes. To meet Timber or one of our other fosters, you will need to fill out an application. After your application is reviewed, one of our volunteers will contact you to set up a time to meet him. Thank you for adopting, not shopping!

Meet Regina! Regina is a 7-year old lab mix looking for a loving home. She came all the way from Texas and was heartworm positive but has now finished her treatment and is ready to find her furever home. We suspect Regina had a pretty rough life before arriving to Pet Tales, therefore she will need someone who is patient and willing to work with her to earn her trust. Regina gets nervous when meeting new people and takes quite a while to feel comfortable, but once she settles in she is a very calm and sweet dog. She prefers a quiet home and gets along with other calm dogs but would also do well as an only dog. She loves spending most of her day relaxing on the couch but also likes to explore the backyard when it’s time for a potty break. Regina also likes to alert you when someone is at the door or if there is a squirrel on the deck. She is the perfect size at 50 lbs and is just looking for someone to love her and provide a safe place to enjoy her golden years.Regina is available for adoption through Pet Tales Rescue in Grand Rapids, MI. Please go to www.pettalesrescue.com and fill out an application. Her adoption fee is $85 plus $15 for her microchip for a total of $100 payable by cash or card through the rescue's website.* Pet Tales Rescue does not have a physical shelter location as all of our pets are in foster homes. To meet Regina or one of our other fosters, you will need to fill out an application. After your application is reviewed, one of our volunteers will contact you to set up a time to meet her. Thank you for adopting, not shopping!

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.Name: MinnieAge: 1 yearGender: FemaleBreed: Dachshund / TerrierWeight: 29 lbsDog friendly: YesCat friendly: Dog savvy catsKid friendly: YesHouse Trained: YesCrate Trained: YesEnergy level: ModerateHistory: From a shelter in TexasAdoption Fee: $400From the Foster:Minnie came to us very pregnant, from a shelter in Texas. We had her in our home for one week before she gave birth to a litter of 8 puppies. She did an amazing job raising her puppies and she is now ready for a loving forever home to call her own.Minnie is such a loving, sweet girl. She get's along very well with our three small resident dogs and all other dogs that we have encountered while out and about. She is pretty interested in our cat so a dog savvy cat or no cat home would probably be best for her. She has never tried to hurt our cat, but does chase her around at times.Minnie is great with going potty outside on a leash. She did have a few accidents when we first got her, but since then she has been doing wonderful. She is crate trained and will go into her crate on demand (although it's not her favorite place). She doesn't bark or cry in there at all and does sleep in a crate all night without making any noises. However, she does great out of her crate during the day while we are out of the house so she will probably prefer a nice soft bed or couch to sleep on vs. being in a crate. She does jump over the puppy/baby gates in our home, but it's only to get to her people and then she is happy as can be.Minnie is absolutely amazing with everyone! She loves kids and adults and just wants to get head scratches and lounge around with you. She is fairly low energy, but does love to go for walks. She loves car rides and happily watches out the window. She is all around a sweet and loving girl that can't wait to find her forever home so she can relax and be part of a family.

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.Name: CuddlesAge: DOB Approx. 6/16/17Gender: FemaleBreed: Heeler xWeight: 44Dog friendly: YesCat friendly: TBDKid friendly: YesHouse Trained: YesCrate Trained: Does fine outEnergy level: ModerateHistory: Pulled from an animal controlAdoption Fee: $400.00From the Foster:Hi! My name is Cuddles, although I am slightly embarrassed to admit that. I do like a good cuddle (my foster dad let me snooze with my head in his lap while he watched TV last night) and particularly a good ear scratch or belly rub, it sounds kind of like I’m a low energy pup. I have my moments of mellow-ness, but I also love a good zoom around the back yard or playing chase orwrasslingwith my foster brother or getting to go for a walk! My foster mom says I could use some work on my leash manners, but I am SO excited to see all there is to see!And Cuddles seems more cutesy than appropriate for my unusual good looks!I just had a bunch of puppies that came up from Texas with me. It is kind of nice to not have to keep an eye on them all the time. Sometimes I still go in Mama-mode and use my mouth to get folks to cooperate. The people remind me they aren’t my pups and I stop, but it probably would be best if there weren’tanyreally littlekids (under 4?) in my forever home. I would like it if there was another pup to play with (one of my foster brothers is an older guy who doesn’t want to play with me, so except for the occasional sniff, I leave him alone) but I’d be fine with just people too!I LOVE people! I’m so excited when my foster mom comes home that I kind of bounce up and down! I do some bouncing and dancing for food too! I like to follow foster mom around the house and see what she is up to! She will often give me some ear scratches if I’m close enough…and did I mention how much I LOVE ear scratches???I love my people so much that I whimper a bit when they leave….eitherthe house or when foster mom goes down those stairs and closes the door behind her (Foster Mom: She settles down pretty quickly). When she leaves the house, she just puts up a gate and I behave myselfpretty well. I did decide to see how tasty a shoe was one day, so now my foster mom makes sure there are no shoes where I can get them and leaves me lots of chew toys.I like tennis balls too…it is so fun to bounce and chase them down the hall!Foster mom says to tell you I totally know to do my business outside (no accidents for this girl!) and that I barkonly occasionally when I see people.Soif you are looking for a pup that will enjoy going for walks or runs or fetching a tennis ball AND also likes to hang out on the sofa and watch a little TV, come and meet me! I’d love it if you’d give me an ear scratch or two!Cuddles is currently being treated for heartworm disease. If you're interested in adopting her, please apply to learn more and speak with our vet team!

Tabbie is a darling senior Rhodesian Ridgeback mix who foster mom is falling in love with in MN... They said \"Oh my goodness we are so in love already!!! We have the most precious foster girl that just arrived today! Senior girl \"Tabby is a rescued stray from Texas. She has been a mommy before and shows signs of a rough previous life with some scarring patches on her rump & all of her joints (usually due to cement.)Her teeth are worn down to nubs or nothing in the front, and she acted like a 13 year old dog when I picked her up... she appeared very depressed with her tail tucked between tween her legs as far as it would go and her head down ? I am happy to report within an hour of bringing her to our home she now is acting like a 3 year old dog playing with my boys & wagging her tail! ? She is such a sweet, calm, gentle girl! She is not a big snuggler yet but I believe she will be in-time when she learns to trust. She did fine in the car but was nervous. She is potty trained, fixed and updated on her shots! She does not like cats! She loves puppies, kids, and other dogs!\" My adoption fee is $200+tax. Our adoption fees include the cost of spay/neuter surgeries, core vaccinations, deworming, and microchipping. NOTE: If an animal is not yet fixed at the time of adoption, a refundable spay/neuter deposit of $100 is required for individuals residing within 100 miles. For adopters further than this, we require a $200 refundable deposit to ensure the pet is brought to their spay/neuter appointment which we schedule and pay for. After proof of surgery is provided the deposit will be fully refunded as long as you do not miss the appointment and provide proof within two weeks of date. You may use card, cash, or a check which we simply hold onto and do not cash (unless the appointment is missed!) Please call 218-632-5938 to check availability, place a hold, or inquire further. A $25 hold guarantees you will be first in line to meet and adopt a pet who is not yet ready to go home or who you want us to hold onto for a day or two until you can visit. If you adopt the hold goes toward the adoption fee. If you decide not to adopt it is consideration a donation to our shelter animals. For more info on our adoption policies including adoption fees visit: http://www.wadenacountyhumanesociety.org/adoption-faqs/ Follow \"Wadena County Humane Society\" on facebook to be first to see our pets as we post them! Thank you for looking to rescue a pet in need!

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.Name: BuckwheatDOB: 04/08/2013Weight: 16Adoption Fee: $325Hi my name is Buckwheat. I came from the warm state of Texas and have had a very Ruff Start. I am a one person type of guy and love other dogs.Once I pick my person I am attached to that person only and do not care for others especially kids. I will need lots of patience and someone who will help me with my quirks. I am kennel trained and will go potty outside on a schedule.I love attention from my person and can tolerate others when being held. I need a companion dog who can show me the ropes of the home and I would love to play with them.I just know there is someone who can work with me and give me the best possible life I can have.My foster mom knows I would be perfect for a one person home with another dog who needs another companion at home. I love my foster mom a lot and cannot wait to have a forever human to love.If you think you can help me find the best possible life please put an application in to meet me.Thanks BuckwheatBuckwheat is heartworm positive. She will need to be treated at one of the fabulous clinics Ruff Start works with in St Cloud or Duluth. Heartworm treatment consists of 3 injections in the pups back. Buckwheat's first injection will be in roughly 30 days and the 2nd and 3rd injections happen 30 days after that. When a dog is going through heartworm treatment, they should be on \"restrictions\" meaning a lot of lap time, crate time and always on a leash. Heartworm disease is NOT contagious, it is transported via mosquitos.An adoption application is the best way to show your interest in an animal. Once we receive your application, a placement coordinator will be in contact with you as soon as possible.Please check out our website, www.ruffstartrescue.org for more details and additional pictures on any of our animals!All Ruff Start dogs and cats are spayed/neutered, up to date on age appropriate vaccines, microchipped, dewormed, and on monthly flea/tick and heartworm prevention (dogs) as well as heartworm tested (dogs).Ruff Start Rescue is a foster based rescue. Animals are located in homes throughout Minnesota. We do not have a facility where animals are kept.Ruff Start Rescue Adoption Policies: http://www.ruffstartrescue.org/info/display?PageID=11744

I was rescued from a region in Texas that is high-kill for dogs in shelters. But thankfully, I was saved from euthanasia and sent to a foster home where I'm preparing for my freedom ride to Wadena County Humane Society. WCHS is expecting an arrival date on or around the 3rd weekend in May. My adoption fee is $200+tax. Our adoption fees include the cost of spay/neuter surgeries, core vaccinations, deworming, and microchipping. NOTE: If an animal is not yet fixed at the time of adoption, a refundable spay/neuter deposit of $100 is required for individuals residing within 100 miles. For adopters further than this, we require a $200 refundable deposit to ensure the pet is brought to their spay/neuter appointment which we schedule and pay for. After proof of surgery is provided the deposit will be fully refunded as long as you do not miss the appointment and provide proof within two weeks of date. You may use card, cash, or a check which we simply hold onto and do not cash (unless the appointment is missed!) Please call 218-632-5938 to check availability, place a hold, or inquire further. A $25 hold guarantees you will be first in line to meet and adopt a pet who is not yet ready to go home or who you want us to hold onto for a day or two until you can visit. If you adopt the hold goes toward the adoption fee. If you decide not to adopt it is consideration a donation to our shelter animals. For more info on our adoption policies including adoption fees visit: http://www.wadenacountyhumanesociety.org/adoption-faqs/ Follow \"Wadena County Humane Society\" on facebook to be first to see our pets as we post them! Thank you for looking to rescue a pet in need!

Hey Y'all  my name is Allie and I've made my way up from Texas to start my life in the beautiful North. I was a stray but you'd never know that with how much I adore everyone. Available for adoption: located in Willmar, MNPinto is a male (neutered), husky mix, approximately 6 years old weighing 50lbs. He LOVES going for walks, being outside and exploring and likes going for car rides. He would do best in a home without cats or other small furry animals. He does ok with other non-dominant, calm dogs. If they leave him alone, he will leave them alone. Pinto is looking for a special family to welcome him into their home. Pinto was transported from Texas to MN back in January by a rescue group. He was successfully treated for Heartworm disease once he got to MN. It is recommended that he should stay on monthly heartworm preventative year round. He was also treated for Ehrlichiosis, a bacterial infection that is spread by ticks. He is not showing any clinical signs of infection. Pinto is also on a special diet to help support his kidney function. He is a great boy that is desperately searching for a family to open their hearts and their home to him.Pinto has been neutered, Heartworm tested and is on preventative, vaccinated for Rabies, Distemper, Bordetella (kennel cough), and has been microchipped. Please email for more information or to set up a time to meet Pinto.

Burt is a sweet, friendly little bundle of happy, wonderful energy. His ideal adopter is someone who can give him the exercise and mental stimulation he needs.  He is just a little thing weighing in at approximately 18 pounds. Burt comes to us from a small rural shelter in Texas where he wasn't getting much interest so he's trying his luck with adopters in the northeast :-)  He is engaged and likes to be with people but true to his breed he needs to stay busy and active. He settled down so nicely after spending a good part of the day outdoors at our dog walk. Burt knows how to sit and loves his treats. Prior to coming into our care, Burt lived in a foster home with cats and dogs but his energy can be a too much for some and he can sometimes be a little testy with cats which should be considered if you have other pets. If you are looking for a  small, active, smart. loving and busy dog, Burt please consider Burt. He is 6 years old and he will be a fun and lively addition to your home and family.
