Hello, EveryPAWdy! My name is Hanny! Pleasure to meet you! If you have a spare moment, I’d love to tell you a bit about myself. I’m about 5-years-old and they say my ears are soft as velvet! My temperament? It’s PAWsum! I’m a friendly boy and a hound through and through. In addition, I’m a good playmate with other doggies. I have never been around meowing friends so I don’t know how I feel about whiskered pals. The rescue thinks I would be okay around kids because I’m so easy going - but they haven’t had a chance to watch me around little humans yet. I came to rescue as a transfer from a shelter in Virginia because my time was up and the shelter was full so they had to make some difficult decisions. Some volunteers really thought I was a cool dog and rallied to get me to a rescue group. I’m so happy I got a second chance! I will be neutered, vaccinated, microchipped and tested for Heartworm prior to official adoption. My energy level is moderate. I’d love someone who can take me on walks or someone who loves the outdoors. I will be your very best pal! If you have a fenced-in yard, that would be a dream for me! I love sniffing fresh air! I’d love to meet you! Please, consider me?

Meet Marvelous MaggieMaggie came from a rural shelter in Virginia. Maggie  is looking for a loving adopter.Maggie is currently fostered inVirginiaMaggie is 9month blue tick coonhound weighs50pounds.Maggie is UTD on shots, spayed, microchipped house and crate trained.Maggie is a very sweet girl who needs a loving safe home.If you would like to adopt Maggie Please contact Kellykswenson1314@gmail.com

Hello my name is Ginger. I was transferred here from another shelter all the way in Virginia! I love to go on walks with my friends and spend time in the shade on a warm day. I got to meet one of my doggy neighbors, and I enjoy doggies who don’t wanna do too much and will give me my space. I could potentially live with kitties if I was introduced properly. I think I’m the cutest girl around, don’t you? How about you take me home with you?If you have children in the family, please bring them in for a visit --it's the best way see if the dog would be a good fit for your family. Adoption applications are only processed after you visit the shelter and meet the dog in person and speak with one of our adoption counselors. The shelter is open Wednesday thru Friday from 1 to 7pm and Saturday from noon to 5pm. Please visitwww.faithfulfriends.us/adoption-process for more information. Email adoptadog@faithfulfriends.us with any questions.

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.All of the animals posted on our site have been temperament tested. While not all are in the immediate area, once we have processed and approved your application, we will move the dog to our adoptive area for you to meet, greet and hopefully adopt. Sometimes we will have more than one application on a dog. That does not mean it automatically goes to another family but you should be aware of the fact that until you are approved and set up for the meet/greet.. the dog could get adopted by another applicant.Mama Sugar came to us from a rural VA pound. She was pregnant and the pound is no place to raise your babies! Sugar and her 2 pups were quickly wrangled into a loving foster home. Her pups are now weaning and mama Sugar is ready for a family of her own. She is being fostered with a child and other dogs.Video: https://www.facebook.com/HighlandHumane/videos/323612414905158/UzpfSTEwMDAwMDc2MDcxODEyMDoyMTIyMzAxNzU3ODA1MTYx/Adoption fee -$150.00 All dogs are spayed/neutered, 4dx heart-worm tested, given Da2PP Bordetella and Rabies vaccines, de-wormed, administered HW monthly prevention and micro-chipped with registration. Apply online:https://www.highlandcountyhumanesociety.org/available-animals/ Email: info@highlandcountyhumanesociety.org Phone: 540.908.9152 Website: www.highlandcountyhumanesociety.orgLike us on FaceBook: www.facebook.com/HighlandHumaneHCHS is 100% foster and volunteer-based (no staff, no employees). All animals for adoption are in foster homes and can be seen by appointment suitable to your schedule. Transportation is available. Save a life! ~ADOPT~

If you are interested in adopting this dog, please download and complete an Adoption Questionnaire from our website and email US at hollyl@k-9lifesavers.orgYou can learn about the adoption process and find a Word, PDF and ONLINE version of the questionnaire by visiting: http://www.k-9lifesavers.org/howtoadopt/.Dog's Name: ForestEstimated Breed : Husky MixApproximate Age: 2 yearsApproximate Weight: approx. 65 lbsCurrently Living at: BoardingAdoption Fee: $300DOG'S DESCRIPTIONForest is a very handsome husky mix with two beautiful different colored eyes! He came to us from rural VA where he was found as a stray. No one came to reclaim him so we scooped him up to give him his second chance! Forest gets along well with other dogs and loves attention from humans! He is a large dog who prefers to be a part of a pack and would prefer to go to a home with another canine buddy. He exhibits strong husky behaviors and would be better suited for somebody who has experience with the breed. He would be happiest in a home with a fenced-in yard.Your new pet will require a refresher in house-training. K-9 Lifesavers strongly recommends all new adopters enroll their new pet into obedience training. This provides for an easier transition into a new home, ensures the dog remains well socialized, and helps form a bond between the dog and the new family.Adoption fees cover basic vetting, spay/neuter surgery (for dogs over 6 months old), rabies, distemper/parvo vaccinations, treatment for worms, heartworm testing, monthly heartworm prevention and monthly flea/tick prevention (while the animal is in our care), and transport costs from high-kill shelter. Please note that on average, K-9 Lifesavers spend significantly more on each dog than their adoption fee. Adoption fee for HW positive dog also covers heartworm treatment at our partner vets.Foster Program: Foster homes provide for the temporary care of a rescue until the dog is placed into a loving, forever home. For more information on becoming a foster parent, and our Foster Program, visit http://www.k-9lifesavers.org/foster/ or email our Foster Coordinator at foster@k-9lifesavers.orgSponsor Me! Make a tax-deductible donation today by visiting us at http://www.k-9lifesavers.org/donate/ . Donations help us offset boarding costs and additional medical treatment for those dogs who need it. K-9 Lifesavers receives NO federal funding and survive with your generous support!For more information on K-9 Lifesavers, or to view a complete listing of all our Adoptable Dogs, visit our website at www.k-9lifesavers.org.Please “like” our Facebook Page for the most current events and new dogs.Thank you for considering a rescue dog!

Meet Lola!  This foxhound mix girl came from a shelter in VA., rescued by a fellow rescue group but sat in a kennel for a year with little to no attention.  She was transferred to us in hopes that she will find her forever home.  She is super sweet, mellow and a great companion dog for an adult home.  She is approx. 4 yrs old.  Good with all, dogs, cats and kids. Stop by our center to meet her.

I came down from Virginia to get some good ol’southern comfort. According to my vet records I lived in a very rural setting with very little (if any) exposure to city noise and people. My foster home is in “the city” so I’m learning what all these new sounds are. Since I’ve had little to no exposure to new people, my foster mom has been helping me learn that new people are good. I like to go and hide and observe new people from a distance and will eventually warm up to new people especially if you give me treats.  I love being outside and rough housing with my foster fur sis. I also love to play fetch and I love all the toys (especially squeaky ones). I like making a pile of all the toys so if I get tired of one, I can play with another - I like keeping my options open. I know where to do my business (outside) and I sleep really good in my kennel. I’d sleep in the bed with you too – I’m the perfect little spoon. I love to go on walks, and I’ve explored a few trails here in Arkansas and I prefer those to a crowded park.  My forever home must have: •	Home with a fenced in yard•	Treasure trove of squeaky toys•	Parent(s) who are at home or can come check on me during the day•	Companion pet – I need someone that can show me the ropes and keep me company while my humans are away•	No cats •	No young kiddos – they’re cute but they make me nervousTRANSPORT AVAILABLE TO APPROVED HOMES! (generally within 1,500 miles)If you are interested in fostering for us, please complete a PRO Volunteer Form: http\://www.pointerrescue.org/volunteer.htmlWant to help but not ready to foster or adopt? PRO is a 501(c)(3) non-profit group; we use donations to pay for all expenses related to caring for the Pointers in our care. Please consider making a donation to help us help dogs like this one! Donations of any size graciously accepted by mail or PayPal, see details here: http://www.pointerrescue.org/donation.html

AriesHi, I am Aries! I am from Virginia and was probably a bird dog who did some hunting and then got lost and found my way to PRO. Now I am a somewhere between a year and two years old, living in my foster home in Northern Virginia, and loving every minute of it!I am currently living with and getting along great with a bossy 3-year-old female dog and a guinea pig.  I have a lot of fun playing with my foster sister.  We love to wrestle, play tag and tug of war.  I’m very well behaved and never get upset when she bosses me around.  I am eager to please and super friendly with people, including kids, dogs and maybe cats. My foster folks think that I would make a wonderful family dog. I would make fast friends with kids, but you might have to watch me around young ones because I still like to jump up.  I would do well with folks who have time to play outside because I love to walk, run, and I think I would really like a dog park.  Whomever I end up with, I hope they will like to play fetch with me. I bring the ball right back to hand. I’m working on basic obedience commands, like ‘sit’ and ‘come’.  I love riding in the car and willing jump right in. I am 100% housebroken. I even use the doggie doorbells to let my foster folks know when I need to go out. I am still young and need appropriate treats and toys to exercise my jaws. I have had a few issues chewing, so I need to go in my crate if I’m not being watched.  I love all kinds of toys and will happily entertain myself with them, but did I mention that I really like to retrieve balls?  When I’m not playing with toys, I’m very cuddly and affectionate. I love to lie in the sun in the afternoons and snuggle up on the sofa in the evening for TV time.   I’ve been with my foster family for four weeks, so they would like you to know that I’m still working on a few things, like leash walking. I don’t pull nearly as badly as some, and I am getting better with practice. I am not used to being crated. I am definitely not a fan and will be sure to voice my displeasure. I don’t mind sleeping in my crate at night, but during the day, I want to be where the action is.  Finally, I want to be around my people above all else. My hope would be to find someone who is around a good bit, perhaps retired, working from home, or able to take me to work with them.  If that’s not possible, I would also probably really like doggy day care.  At home, a fenced in yard would be needed, (you know how hard it is for us dogs to resist the temptation of a squirrel or bird). I am very treat motivated and a quick learner, so I could be trained to an invisible fence. I am fully-grown and weigh 56 pounds.  The vet says I should put on a few more pounds and I’m really enjoying trying to do that.  I was recently microchipped and neutered. I am current on all required vaccinations and put on a monthly flea/tick and heartworm preventatives. I have also been dewormed. I am well behaved for nail trimming, ear cleaning, bathing and brushing.  The vet said I’m a perfect gentleman.  TRANSPORT AVAILABLE TO APPROVED HOMES! (generally within 1,500 miles)Interested in fostering? Fill out our volunteer application here: http:// www.pointerrescue.org/ helpus.htmlTRANSPORT AVAILABLE TO APPROVED HOMES! (Generally, within 1500 miles)Can't foster right now, but want to help?Consider sponsoring a dog by making a donation to help with vetting costs. PRO is 501c3 non-profit and is fully funded by donations, your tax-deductible gift would be greatly appreciated! http:// www.pointerrescue.org/ donation.html

Sampson was the last of the dogs owned by backyard breeders and was kept as an outside dog all his life. They wanted to travel and had no one to take care of Sampson, so they dumped him at the shelter. Sampson is very unsocialized, but is improving. Once he warms up to a person, he is very social and lovable. At the shelter, one of the Animal Control Officers would sing to him and he would do the “Akita Happy Dance”. He is currently being kenneled and adores the kennel owner. He is slowly coming out of his shell, day by day, person by person. When he was initially transported from Lee County to Richmond Va, he was so terrified at the transfer point that he just flattened on the ground. He had to be lifted into the second transport vehicle. He showed no aggression at any point during his handling. In a couple of weeks, the kennel owner was able to get him in the car with a little coaxing to take him to the vet. Again, while fearful of the circumstances, he was great with the vet and the staff. Here is what the volunteers who went to walk him had to say:'Samson notes: He is a big boy! He is shy, and a bit slow to warm up (of course all of them absolutely adore Stacey - comments are limited to how the dogs react to us). He's not aggressive - just wary. Walks reasonably well on lead, and actually seemed to enjoy his walk-about.' He seems to be one of those dogs who has to warm up to each person he meets, but then is polite and even sociable.Sampson is looking for a foster home to help him on his journey towards adoption.

Prince couldn’t  have been giving a more appropriate name! Prince is calm, caring, easy going and a joy to be around. All our dog walkers love him! Prince is a 7 plus year old redbone coonhound mix. He came to us from Virginia where he was found as a stray. The person that found him called the owner that was on his tag and they did not want him back because “he was useless”!!! As sad as that’s may seem this was the best thing that ever happened to Prince. Now he can finally have a real home where he is loved and spoiled for the rest of his days. No more chains, no more chasing animals through the woods! Finally gets a comfy couch and a person to call his own. Prince is good with dogs, but really wants an old friend to hangout with rather then a playmate. He did fine when he met cats here, but did want to chase the neighbors cat that was outside, typical coonhound behavior. We are very excited for Prince to finally have a family or person to truly love him for the amazing dog he is! Adoption fee-$100

Anthony and Lucy came to us from Virginia. Their owner was loosing his battle with cancer and he asked to have them brought up north where they could find a home. Anthony is a handsome 6 to 7 yr old piebald Dachshund and Lucy is a 10 to 12 yr old Miniature Dachshund. They are both friendly dogs, but are used to living in a quiet home with an older man, so they would do best in a home without children. They lived with a cat in the previous home and have done well with the dogs they have met while here. They both go in for dentals on 6/20 and can be adopted after then. They do not have to be adopted together, but are good friends and have been together for a few years and are currently kenneled together here. Adoption fee-     Anthony- $250     Lucy- $100     Both-$300

Emma is a very special beagle that came to us last May from Virginia very Pregnant. Emma gave birth to 11 healthy puppies and was a great mom. Emma has been in a foster home and she gets along very well with other dogs and cats. Emma walks well on a leash. She is very calm and loves people. Emma is working on her housebreaking, but is getting better everyday. She gets anxious in a car, so short trips are best for her. Emma's favorite spot is cuddled up next to a person or another dog! After all her puppies were gone we were finally able to work on Emma's health issues. Emma has environmental allergies and was put on antibiotics and Cyclosporine. Her skin got better and then she had to go through heartworm treatments. She has had all three treatments and has been spayed. We found that the Cyclosporine was not working and she has been on Apoquel the last few months and between that and weekly medicated baths Emma is feeling a lot better! Emma is an amazing dog and a a joy to be around. She will make some lucky person very happy, could that be you?! Adoption fee-$200 Emma is not at the shelter but is being fostered by an employee and can be brought anytime to be seen.

I’m a big goofball who loves attention and cuddles.  I like most everyone I meet but I can be a little shy around some men.  I love toys!  I didn’t even know what they were before but now I think they are great fun.  I make a silly toothy grin when I get excited that will make you smile.  I’m a very affectionate guy once I get to know you.  I get along with my canine foster brothers too!   I’m lucky to have such a wonderful foster home because I have come a long way from the dog I was when I first came from Virginia, still recovering from my surgeries to repair the severely embedded collar I suffered.   I’m crate trained and house trained.  I walk nicely on a leash too.  I’m pretty much an all-around dreamboat just waiting for the right family to choose me!  Apply now at www.coldnosewarmheart.orgTHE BREED MIX LISTED IS OUR BEST ESTIMATE BASED ON THE DOG'S PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS.  IT IS NOT A GUARANTEE OF THE ACTUAL BREED/S.

When we named Miss Nellie, we thought that she was on the verge of being a senior dog. Now that she is healthy and happy; we can confidently say that she has a long way to go before she is a senior. We now call her Scooter; which better describes her personality and her propensity to get frequent attacks of the Zoomies.She came to us from a rural shelter in southwestern Virginia. She was malnourished, infested with intestinal parasites, and her fur was coming out in clumps. We were also concerned that she may be pregnant. During her wellness check, it was discovered she was indeed pregnant, but the vet felt something was wrong. An ultrasound was preformed and we found out her babies were not viable.  She needed emergency surgery.  If we had waited few more days; she may have not survived.  After a few weeks of recovery at her new foster home in South Carolina; the real Scooter showed herself.. Her coat is soft, full and beautiful. She loves to run around her wooded fenced property chasing away squirrels and any other critter bold enough to trespass.  Due to this, we think she would do best in a home without cats.  She likes going for leash walks and really loves to snuggle with her foster mom.  Scooter gets along with her big ACD foster brother, but is not very fond of other female dogs.  Scooter is deaf, She may hear really low and high pitched loud sounds. For this reason, we feel a fenced yard is really important for her safety.  She is learning some sign language.  Like most ACD's Scooter is wary of new people until she gets to know them; then she quickly warms up for petting and treats.. She is a goofy, happy girl.  She is crate trained and likes to go for car rides. She has been a very good girl at all of her vet visits and with everyone she traveled with on her journey from Bristol, VA to Richmond, VA and onto Summerville, SC She is still learning about toys, squeaky ones are really fun.We think Scooter is about  4yrs old, and 35 LBS, She is Heartworm negative, up to date on her vaccinations, crate trained, house trained, spayed, and being fostered near Summerville, SCIf you are interested in adopting Scooter, please visit the Adoption Process page on our website – http://carolinasrescue.com/Adoption_Process.html. You can download our Adoption Questionnaire there, then email it to us at adoptions@carolinasrescue.com. That will start the process.

Tiki was rescued from a rural Virginia animal shelter. He arrived as a stray, though the employees strongly thought that the people that turned him in were in fact his owners. He's an adorable 20 lb terrier mix, and while we really have no clue what he is mixed with, he resembles a cairn terrier with the size and curled tail of aSpitz.He is estimated to be approximately 2 years old. He's done great with other dogs and is brushing up on his housebreaking routine. He has a little bit of a pushy terrier attitude and doesn't like fast movements towards him, so we are restricting him to a home with no young children at this time. He walks great on a leash and is enjoying all the attention that he can get. He is fully vetted, microchipped, neutered and maintained on flea/tick/heartworm prevention. His adoption fee is $200 which helps to offset his veterinary expenses. For more information on Tiki, email petlover_42@yahoo.com.

Thank you for your interest in dog who needs a new home. Adoption can be one of the most fulfilling experiences in your life and especially in the life of your new canine companion.A note to those looking at CPR. We have no perfect dogs - but many of our dogs have proven to be perfect for a certain someone. Our job is to find those someone's. Our most successful adopters come to CPR not because they want a dog. They come to us because they want to give a dog a home. We urge all of our potential adopters not to fall in love with a picture. While we like to know what you like in looks, a dog is more than a pretty face. Our goal is to match you with the best possible pet for you and your home. We want to create furever families.Our descriptions contain all that we know about this dog today. We'll update as more information is known.Are you looking to adopt within the next 30 days? If so please visit our webpage at www.carolinapoodlerescue.org and complete the application. You'll find it in the menu on the left hand side. You'll also find a total listing of all our dogs available.Just browsing but interested in poodles and poodle mixes? Please drop a note to applications@carolinapoodlerescue.org with your name, address and phone # and email. We'll add you to our mailing list.thanksthe CPR Adoption teamDate into Rescue: 4/5/2019Reason for being in rescue: VA shelter- allowed to run at large and picked up one too many timesFoster location: Dreamweaver Farms, Pacolet SCSpecial Needs? Dette was deemed a dangerous animal in the state of Virginia. Her previous owner would not keep her confined and she was allowed to roam at will. She is happy and gregarious and would run up to people and knock them down as a game. She's not shown any aggressive side to us at all but we all know how to tell her \"GET OFF\" and she's respecting that cue. She needs some training and someone with some common sense. Dette CAN NOT GO BACK TO THE STATE OF VIRGINIA. EVER.Weight: 80 lbsHeight: 25 inSpayed/Neutered: YesAdoption Fee: $499Fence needed? Without exception and it needs to be a solid, dependable fence and you need to plan to be in control of your dog.What kind of home would be best for me? Dette's perfect owner will be someone with dog experience, who loves to take long, brisk walks and who would enjoy teaching, shaping and training their dog to be the excellent companion this dog has the potential to be. Dette is affectionate and friendly and longs for that companion that will be her partner, her friend and her guide through life instead of letting him run amuck.What is my personality like? Dette is a wide open kind of girl with zero attention span right now because no one has asked anything of her. That needs to change. She is a highly intelligent dog and because she has been allowed to run and roam she got into trouble. She was part of a pack with her brother Dood and was allowed too much freedom and not enough structure and training.One of our temperament programs is to take our dogs off site for adventures. Dette is a good girl in the car. She notices things but does not necessarily hyper focus on any one thing. She enjoyed the trip in the car just as she enjoyed the trip from Virginia to South Carolina.How do I act when I first meet new people? Cautious at first and then she warms up.Other tips and tidbits: Estimated Birthdate: 4/15/2015. Dette is a lot of dog with a lot of things going for her. She has been given a very bad rap and very nearly lost her life because her previous owner had no common sense. We are going to be extraordinarily picky about her next home to make sure it's her best home and her forever home.Dood and Dette are brother and sister and that is a problem. They will not be placed together. They egg each other on. They need separate homes and to go live their own lives.House trained? Dogs can be house trained if they are in the right environment and are allowed to follow a schedule as long as a physical reason doesn't keep them from being trained. A dog house trained in my home may not be in yours. We will help you teach your new dog this necessary skill and based on your schedule.Please note - we do not ship dogs. If you are interested in adopting, please take a look at the distance between the foster home location and your location and make sure you are willing to make that trip. Most of our dogs are at our farm in Pacolet, South Carolina.To apply, please visit our webpage at www.carolinapoodlerescue.org and visit the tab on the left that directions you to the online application.Please note that when screening applications, we look at the entire home and then make suggestions based on what would be a good fit for your home. You are not being screened for a specific dog although we are looking to see what type of dog interests you - poodles or non poodles, color, age, etc. Others here may be a better fit for you. It is very difficult to get to know a living animal from a picture and a short description. Since we are constantly getting in new dogs, this may be a dog not in our listings yet. We want you to be very happy with your new companion and will make suggestions based on what you tell us about you.Thank you for considering CPR.

Kenzie came to Eunoia Rescue from Lee County more than a year and a half ago! This poor girl lived a rough life prior to coming to us, and had babies by the time she was a year old. Unfortunately some of the trauma Kenzie experienced early in life has stuck with her, and because of that Kenzie needs to be an only animal. She does great with all humans, and has even had extensive training with K-9 Good Manners! She is very well behaved, but has a lot of energy so will do best with someone who lives an active lifestyle. If you’re interested in giving Kenzie the home she’s always dreamed of, send us a message!

PLEASE READ ENTIRE BIO>>>This cute little gal was surrendered to a high-kill, rural county shelter when she was only 8 weeks old. When the shelter asked us to take Teeny and her three sisters, we were more than happy to do so! We were told the pups were born on 1/21/19 and that they were Chihuahua mixes but we think there's some Beagle or some kind of small terrier or maybe even some Shelty in them, too. All four pups are super sweet, energetic, and playful. They love romping around with each other so we think a home that has another similar-sized, canine-friendly dog would give Teeny not only a playmate but a role-model as well. After all, there's a lot she needs to learn! Her adopter will need experience, patience and adequate time to supervise, guide and teach her all she'll need to know in order to grow up to be a well-mannered dog. Keep this in mind if you work long hours and/or have a busy social life that would limit the amount of time you'd have for Teeny. A home with a secure fenced yard will give Teeny the safe environment she needs to play and 'do her business.' Right now, she thinks anything she can get in her mouth or her mouth around is a chew toy and, take it from us - her little teeth are needle sharp! If there are young children living in or frequently visiting your home, an older pup or an adult dog that is not quite so mouthy might be a better fit. After all, a nip or scratch still hurts even if it's the result of playful behavior. To adopt Teeny, just stop by the shelter and ask to meet her. NOTE: Until Teeny is old enough to be spayed, we are only accepting applications from residents of Jefferson County. /// TEENY IS SPONSORED THRU JUNE 2019 BY JACK NALLY IN LOVING MEMORY OF ROTTEN ROTTIE, A MUCH-LOVED ACS ALUMNI. Primary Color: White Secondary Color: Brown Weight: 7.3lbs Age: 0yrs 5mths 1wks I am available for adoption at the Animal Care Society.

Kong is a 1.5 year old, 10-pound male min pin/chi mix from a large hoarding rescue situation in the DC area. Heis still scared and getting used to being around people in his now-safe foster home. This gorgeous boy would do well in a home withother dogs toshow him how to love. His foster mom says he watches her intently, but doesn't get too close yet. Kongneeds time and patience so that he can gain confidence and trust.He likes the safety of his crate - it makes him feelcozy and comfortable - his own space. His foster mom believes he is happy, just timid. Pee pad trained but not going outside for walks yet.Vaccinated, microchipped, andheartworm negative. Hoarder dogs can make the best pets. They are sweet, loyal and often calm. Hoarder dogs can be very shy. The one thing they need from their adoptive family isn't the toys and treats (although treats always help!) is time. http://fosterdogstories.blogspot.com/2013/02/adopting-hoarder-dog.html?m=1Please contact us DIRECTLYusing the instructions belowif you are interested in fostering or adopting one of our Waggytails!Visit our website (www.waggytailrescue.org) for an adoption or foster application.It is important to fill out an application as soon as possible for consideration, andwe require a complete application for you to meet an animal. Attach your completed application to an email with the dog's name in the title, and send to:Adoptions:waggyadopt@gmail.comFosters:waggyvolunteer@gmail.comPLEASE NOTE: Dogs marked \"Adoption Pending\" have anapproved adoption applicationon file and are awaiting final approval. Check back in a few days to see if they are still available!We understand you may have questions, but the fastest way to get answers is to completethe application and the fosterparent can then answer questions!Waggytail Rescue CANNOT guaranteethe exact age of any adoptable dog, or final size of any of our adoptable puppies. We rely on the information provided to us by veterinarians, shelters, owner surrenders and other circumstances bringing the dog into our rescue

Fawn isa 3-year-old, 12-pound female min pinmix. She comes to us from a large hoardingrescue case near DC.She is in a foster home and still scared of being touched - human contact is new to her. Fawn will jump on her foster mom's bed to sleep, rather than in her crate. She runs away at any sudden movements and sometimes howls at nothing. This pretty girl is slowly coming around and showing her curious side, beginning to play with toys. Fawn likes to look out the window. Fawn is spayed, vaccinated, microchipped, andheartworm negative.Not yet house-trained.Hoarder dogs can make the best pets. They are sweet, loyal and usually fairly calm. Hoarder dogs are oftenvery shy.The one thing they need from their adoptive family isn't the toys and treats (although treats always help!) is time. http://fosterdogstories.blogspot.com/2013/02/adopting-hoarder-dog.html?m=1.Please contact us DIRECTLYusing the instructions belowif you are interested in fostering or adopting one of our Waggytails!Visit our website (www.waggytailrescue.org) for an adoption or foster application.It is important to fill out an application as soon as possible for consideration, andwe require a complete application for you to meet an animal. Name: TitusBreed: Labradoodle (Schnoodle?)Approximate Age: 15-17 months oldApproximate Weight: 50 lbs (underweight)Personality:affectionate, energetic, playful Observations with Dogs: goodObservations with Cats: goodObservations with Kids: not good with young childrenCurrently Living at: DC area foster home**EXPERIENCED ADOPTERS WITH NO YOUNG CHILDREN ONLY**Titus is a gorgeous Doodle... sometimes he looks more Lab/Poodle mix, while other times he looks more Schnauzer/Poodle mix. Whatever he is, he is gorgeous and affectionate.Titus was adopted from us as an older puppy in January and returned because living with toddlers proved to be too stressful for him. As such, he cannot go to a home with children under 12 years old (out of an abundance of caution).This dog needs A LOT of exercise... seriously, take what you think is an appropriate amount of exercise for an older puppy and at least double it. His previous adopters struggled initially because they weren't giving him anywhere near he amount of exercise he needed. Because their schedules didn't allow for running with him or spending time at the dog park, we suggested day care and that absolutely did the trick and helped him be a calm boy indoors.In his final month with his previous adopters, he began to exhibit resource guarding tendencies (with the children only). In his current foster home, he only exhibits some mild resource guarding with the resident dog; the humans are able to handle his bowl and food, take it away, etc. with no issues. That all said, Titus' forever family will need to be mindful and careful, only feeding him in his crate and not introducing high value toys or treats until he is settled in.Titus also has separation anxiety, which seems to be on the mild end of the spectrum as it became better when his previous adopters provided adequate exercise. His current foster family reports no signs of separation anxiety, but they do have a second dog, which sometimes can help alleviate milder cases. As such, Titus would do best in a home with a confident second dog. Either way, his adopter will need to commit to working with an approved trainer to help him overcome his anxiety since having a second dog is merely a band-aid and doesn't address the underlying issues. He could also use some training on greeting visitors (he's a jumper!) and just being more gentle and polite in general. He is a smart boy and a quick learner... it helps that he is very treat motivated.If you're scared off, then Titus is not the dog for you. If you are an experienced Doodle person and/or have managed mild separation anxiety and mild resource guarding, then you just might be a good match for this boy.Please note that we will be evaluating applicants VERY carefully to ensure his next forever home will truly be his forever home. We are all-volunteer and suspect we will be flooded with applications, so please be patient as we do our job and match him to the best adopter. When he has a pending adopter, we will note it on this profile.Titus is very affectionate with his humans and other dogs, and did well with cats as a younger pup, though he realistically may have too much energy to enable a peaceful existence for a resident cat. This boy needs a bit of work, but he is so worth it and will repay you with undying loyalty and companionship.Like most shelter dogs, Titus may need a refresher on housetraining and crate training. We ask all of DC PAWS’ fosters to work on both house and crate training with their foster dog.If you are interested in adopting Titus, please submit an adoption application at http://dcpawsrescue.org/adoption-application/.DC PAWS Rescue does our best to provide accurate and complete information about our adoptable animals. Please note that we cannot make any guarantees about age or breed; we rely upon our rescue partners and their veterinarians to make those assessments. We also cannot make any guarantees about housebreaking and animal temperament, as animals can behave differently through transition and in different environments.Our shelter partners provide a basic vet screening for each animal we rescue, which includes necessary vaccinations, deworming, microchipping, and spay/neuter (unless the animal is too young or otherwise deemed by the vet to not be a good candidate for surgery). Please note that this is not a comprehensive medical exam and as such, may not identify any and all medical issues, though our goal is to flag any obvious health issues through the basic vet screening. We share all medical records with adopters and flag any known issues prior to adoption finalization. About DC PAWS RescueOur rescue is an all-volunteer, foster-based dog and cat rescue in the DC area. We rescue from rural areas in the south, as well as local DC area shelters, such as Prince Georges County, MD and Wicomico County, MD.BE A FOSTER:Fosters make it possible for DC PAWS to save and care for homeless, neglected and abandoned animals! To learn about fostering dogs or cats for DC PAWS Rescue, please visit: http://dcpawsrescue.org/volunteer/fostering/foster-applicationBE A SPONSOR:For any of our animals! Sponsors help us provide critical medical care, food, boarding and other support for animals facing euthanasia. Individuals who sponsor a dog or cat receive special recognition on the animal's profile.  Sponsorships can also be made in honor or memory of a loved one, and you may designate to whom DC Paws Rescue should provide notice of your gift. To learn more about sponsorship, please visit: http://dcpawsrescue.org/donate/

p.p1 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 13.0px 'Comic Sans MS'; -webkit-text-stroke: #1d2129}p.p2 {margin: 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px 0.0px; font: 13.0px 'Comic Sans MS'; -webkit-text-stroke: #1d2129; min-height: 18.0px}span.s1 {font: 14.0px 'Helvetica Neue'; font-kerning: none; color: #1d2129; background-color: #ffffff}span.s2 {font-kerning: none}COURTESY POST -Juliet is in need of a new home. She has been with her current family since she was adopted from a local shelter as a puppy. They are heartbroken to lose her, but feel that Juliet would be a happier dog with a different family/home situation. She is a beautiful and spunky 4 yr young 75 lb lab mix, spayed, current on all vaccines and no health issues and perfectly house trained. Juliet adores people and kids (because of her energy and strength she should be watched around small children). She is the biggest lover of people - loyal, affectionate, intelligent, highly trainable, protective, energetic, strong, sweet, in need of human love and interaction, good listener, senses emotion, loves to hang with her owners, needs daily exercise, needs routine, needs alpha management. She is a wonderful protector of home and family and will bark loudly and menacingly at strangers who approach the house until she officially meets them. She is anxious away from her owners and does not do well in kennels, she needs in-home boarding (at owner's home or in home of sitter.)Juliet is an alpha dog and needs a firm and consistent hand which is not possible in her current situation. Juliet’s ideal owner would be an experienced and alpha dog owner (single person, couple or family with children experienced with dogs) who could love and spend time with her, manage her firmly, and keep a routine for her. She does fine when home alone during the day as long as she knows her owners will return after work. She will do better with fewer handlers who can use the same training methods with her (e.g. we have too many handlers -- nanny, babysitters, housekeeper, dog walker, husband, wife, kids) Active owners - and with a yard - would be ideal.Juliet cannot be with other dogs at this time - while she loves certain dogs that she knows, she has shown aggression with other dogs. She loves flirting with cats on walks, but it is unknown how she would do with a cat in the home. She shows aggression towards large dogs and needs active training before any further interaction with dogs. Juliet should not interact off leash with dogs until further training. Her current dog trainer located in Washington, DC has offered free training to the new owners.All requests for information will be handled by Juliet’s owner and should be directed to Katie at 202-258-2362 or email rehomingjuliet@gmail.com.

Brew came to us as a transfer from a Washington rescue where he was surrendered by his owners.  Although we did not get much information on his background, we understand he was reported to be mostly kept outside and had a slight apprehension towards men.  The trainer had a male stranger greet him and although he was alert and watchful, he did obey the cue to sit and nicely took a treat.  This shows us that Brew can work through any fear of men as long as he is given choices and not forced, and as long as positive rewards are used to create a happy association.  Brew is about 2.5 years old, he is fine with other dogs, and we will post more as we get to know him better.  Staff guesses as to his breed mix include Shepherd, Lab, Rhodesian Ridgeback, and maybe even Australian heeler.Brew's adoption fee is $175 and includes neuter, current vaccines, microchip, free vet visit, 30 days free pet health insurance, and custom engraved ID tag.

Calista came to us as a transfer from a Washington rescue.  She is such a friendly, outgoing, and energetic young dog.  She loves playtime with other dogs, and when shes not too excited, she knows how to sit on cue.  She loves yummy treats, so training should be a breeze as long as its force free!  Calista is 1.5 years old and apparently was surrendered to the WA rescue because she is not good with cats and livestock.  She will chase for sure, but with other dogs, she's a super star.  She will make someone a great outdoor activity companion.  Dont let her silly expression fool you on her profile photo, she is beautiful, she's alert, and displays a nice confidence.  Calista's adoption fee is $200 and includes spay, current vaccines, microchip, free vet visit, 30 days free pet health insurance, and custom engraved ID tag.

Animal Profile: Max is an 18-month-old, 67 lb male Dutch Shepherd mix who is smart, athletic and loves to play with other dogs. He is crate trained and house trained and has basic obedience training. He will thrive with a dog-savvy owner who will provide him mental and physical stimulation to keep him fulfilled. He has been respectful of the dog-savvy cat in his foster home, though he may not do well with skiddish cats. We would like to place Max in a home without small children due to his enthusiastic play style. His ideal family will participate with Max in dog sports -- possibly agility, rally, nose work or even dock diving! We'll add more information about Max as we get to know him.Adoption Info: Adoption fee is $400, which includes spay/neuter, current rabies/DAPPV/bordetella vaccinations, microchip, health certificate, and heartworm test. All adoption fees are donations to a Washington non-profit corporation and all donations go to benefit the animals in our rescue. Apply online at www.DogGoneSeattle.orgAnimal History: This dog was transferred from our rescue partner Tacoma Humane Society in Washington.

* Female Chihuahua mix* Approximately 1 year old* Approximately 5 pounds* House trained* Crate trained* Okay with other dogs, not sureabout cats* Not good with children* Adoption fee: $285All dogs with PUP are in private foster homes so we can provide our potential adopters the most current information available.Raising a puppy requires a lot of work and is a commitment! Rosa will be an awesome addition to a family that can give her the attention, exercise, training and affection she deserves.Due to the fact that this is a mixed breed puppy, we, nor our vets, cannot guarantee the size that your dog will be.Health:Rosahas been spayed and microchipped. She is current on her DHPP, Bordetella, and Rabies. She has been wormed and flea treated.She has been tested for heart worm.She has been diagnosed with recurrent struvite bladder crystals and requires a special diet.History: Rosa comes from a local Washington shelter. PUP was asked to help and we are happy to help her find her forever home!Notes from Rosa's Foster Home: Since coming to PUP, this extra-sweet girl has proven to be such a delightful dog! Very shy and unsure at first, Rosa has made great strides and her true personality is shining through. It didn’t take long for her to wiggle her way into our hearts!Rosa is crate trained and housetrained on a schedule. She gets very excited when she sees her leash and has no trouble doing a 3+ mile walk. This smart girl is very food-motivated when training and we work on basic commands every day, such as ‘sit’, ‘wait’, ‘leave it’ and ‘off’. She really enjoys toys and playing with other dogs. She is proving to be a great little retriever, too! Rosa has become much more comfortable when out and about. She loves to be busy during the day and then snuggle on an open lap come evening. During the cold months, her most favorite place in the house is in a cozy bed in front of the fireplace. Her daily antics are so amusing and she makes us laugh and smile every day.Whatever may be part of her past has caused Rosa to be cautious around strangers and she prefers getting to know people slowly and in her own time. She requires a calm, predictable routine and time to feel comfortable in new surroundings and with new people. However, once comfortable, look out! She just explodes with personality!Rosa has been diagnosed with ‘bladder crystals’. Crystals are concentrates of naturally occurring minerals in a dog's urine which can occur due to abnormal urine pH. Rosa requires a strict diet of a prescription food to manage this issue. She needs to have water available at all times as well as the opportunity to get outside frequently. The cost of her food runs about $15 per month.We are looking for a family who will continue provide Rosa with loving, patient companionship and is also willing to manage her urinary issues; this includes not being gone for more than a few hours at a time during the day. Rosa would also enjoy having a playful canine companion in her new home. Having a fireplace is also a plus! She will do best in a home with easy access to a yard so she can get outside often.Rosa is truly ‘a keeper’ and it will be very hard to let her go! She looks forward to wiggling her way into your heart!Note: The above description reflects the behavior we have observed in the dog's foster home. Although PUP provides adopters up to the minute information on our dogs, we cannot guarantee they will behave in the same manner in a different environment with new owners.ADOPTION: If you think you have room in your home and heart for this dog and you reside within Washington State, please go to our Adoption Information page, or copy and paste this link https://www.pupdogrescue.org/adopt.html in your browser. There you will find more information and be able to fill out an adoption application.EVENTS: To attend our next PUP adoption event, please check out our Facebook page, or copy and paste this link https://www.facebook.com/pg/puprescue/events/?ref=page_internal in your browser.Can you help save more dogs by Fostering?Become our fan on Facebook! Or follow us on Twitter!

Hi, my name is TOMMY and I would love to meet you. I am a Neutered Male Labrador Retriever and Pit Bull Terrier. The shelter staff think I am about 3 years old. I have been at the shelter since Apr 24, 2019.  Meet Tommy! This sweet boy was transferred to the shelter from one of our partner shelters in central Washington because they had too many dogs. Tommy was a shelter favorite at his previous shelter - his goofy and affectionate personality won over everyone he met. He is social, active, and always down to play. Tommy has been adopted a returned a few times so he really is looking for a family that can commit to meeting his needs and has the time and patience to do a lot of training. This boy has been through a lot, but he is the forgive and forget type - with his charming nature he makes friends easily. Tommy would do great with training based on positive reinforcement, he is highly motivated by food, attention and toys. He is ready for an active lifestyle with plenty of exercise, so apartment living is not a good fit and he is best suited for older kids or adults. Tommy is ready to meet his new family today!

Animal Profile: Seymour is an 18-month-old male Catahoula mix who is a lanky, athletic 70 lbs. He is a happy, goofy, sweet guy who enjoys getting pets, snuggling, playing fetch and chewing on bones. He is still young and excitable so he'll need a patient, understanding family that's dedicated to continuing his training. Seymour is such a smart boy and learns new commands and tricks very quickly. Because of his size and intelligence, we feel he will do best with a dog-savvy leader. He is leash trained, crate trained, place trained and knows many commands including sit, down, shake, no, and come. Being a hunting breed, he has a prey drive so he'll need a forever home without cats. Seymour plays really well with other dogs once he has a slow, proper introduction. (When he first meets dogs he can be a bit over-excited/anxious and needs help introducing himself properly.) He loves to run and we would love to see him go to a home that can give him lots of activity or a yard to do zoomies in! Seymour will make a great companion for an active family who can include him on their adventures!Adoption Info: Adoption fee is $400, which includes spay/neuter, current rabies/DAPPV/bordetella vaccinations, microchip, health certificate, and heartworm test. All adoption fees are donations to a Washington non-profit corporation and all donations go to benefit the animals in our rescue. Apply online at www.DogGoneSeattle.orgAnimal History: This dog was transferred from our rescue partner at PAWS in Washington.

Rollie is a bluetick coonhound who came up from West Virginia.  He is very shy and scared right now and really needs a home soon!  He is a loving boy who likes to play with volunteers and the other dogs, and with patience we think he will do well.  He is a gentle soul!!

Meet Lucinda aka Lucy!!! She came to us heavily pregnant from West Virginia. Her pups have all been adopted and now momma need a home!! She is a small terrier mix (15-20lbs) about 1-2 years old. She has terrier tendencies and because of this we think a home with older children would be best.Here is what her foster has to say:Lucy is lovable and cuddly and cute as the dickens. She likes to be around people, usually snuggled up next to them. She loves riding in the car and being outside. She likes to chase balls and other toys. A tennis ball is the perfect size for her. She loves to jump and can walk and hop on her hind legs.Lucy chews paper and slippers, but not shoes. She is crate trained, but not totally house trained yet. She has to learn to tell you when she needs to go outside. She play nips at you to get your attention, and we are working to break her of this habit. She barks at people to get their attention so they will love her. She also barks at every dog and cat she sees on the street. Lucy does not like the cat in her foster home and would do best with more submissive dogs. She thinks she rules the roost. ??If interested in Lucy, apply online!!!

YoYo came to NYC from a rural shelter in West Virginia. We don't know his history before he came to us but as we've gotten to know him, we've discovered some of his quirks, including that he is deaf. YoYo can be startled easily due to his hearing loss and would do best in an experienced, adult only home. He has worked with our trainer and made significant progress in many areas but he will need continued training in his new home. Come and visit him Tuesdays through Friday if you're interested in meeting him!

The first thing you notice about Chatter is that she can't stop, well...chattering. She is a talkative lady which is true to her breed and is always ready to let you know what is going on with her distinctive Hound bay. Her moniker is fitting in more ways than one as she loves to chatter and to chat with her human friends. Being a Hound means that Chatter's nose is always on the go and she always knows when you have recently had lunch and will sniff out any crumbs left over. She is pretty much a canine vacuum, and we say that with fondness, and her nose is sniffing out the next treat it can find!Chatter is a recent transplant from our rescue partner in West Virginia, and from her physical state it seems as if this lady had recently had a litter or puppies or had had previous litters. For a dog as clever and driven as Chatter is (usually for food), we would love to see her put those mothering days behind her and be spoiled in her very own home. Special note to all of our Hound fans; she is as beautiful in person as she is in her photos and just as chatty! Come meet this Chatty Cathy today, and foster or adopt her! You will never run out of things to talk about with Chatter around!The link to our online application is here: https://goo.gl/q6QRJe

Not many dogs have a prefix attached to their name, and not many dogs are like Mr. Pricklepants. Stately, dignified and the picture of a senior gentleman, Mr. Pricklepants is one unique individual. When you first meet Mr. Pricklepants, you might assume he is aloof or standoffish. With a few treats and an abundance of pets, he quickly turns into your BFF. Many assume he is a low-key and easygoing senior, which he is 97% of the time, but the other 3% is pure enthusiasm. Mr. Pricklepants enjoys nothing more than getting out and about in the yard where he can run to his heart's content. Mr. Pricklepants is a dog with a story to tell: he came to us from our rescue partner in West Virginia, where he had been a primarily outdoor dog before coming to their shelter. He was a favorite of the staff and volunteers who saw just how special this senior guy is when he opens up. Mr. Pricklepants is truly an ideal companion for a family that wants a dog for nice long walks around the neighborhood, but who would equally be as comfortable watching a movie or Sunday night football. Stop by the shelter today and ask about fostering or adopting this awesome senior guy!The link to our online application is here: https://goo.gl/q6QRJe

Please note-we do require an application, found on our website, almosthomedogs.org, click on adopt, prior to any meet and greets.   APPLICATION LINK   https://docs.google.com/forms/d/12OTN3QBcNJEXlyQM0GzTMrb5ErkjpgWV3MiSlUP0L64/Introducing Ivy.  She is looking for a very special home.  Ivy was rescued from a very rural part of West Virginia with her two young babies and is now finished raising them.  Ivy is young and only about 23 pounds.  She is very sweet, thriving in her foster home with her babies, her foster mom and another small dog but she is very timid.  She will need a quiet home, a patient owner.  She will be a wonderful loyal dog but need some time to adjust, build some trust and confidence.  Ivy is very gentle. Because our dogs are in foster homes, applications are required prior to setting up any appointments.  Calling or emailing may delay your consideration.  Find our application on our website, almosthomedogs.org or click link below to find our application. https://docs.google.com/forms/d/12OTN3QBcNJEXlyQM0GzTMrb5ErkjpgWV3MiSlUP0L64/edit?ts=5a7f738fAdoption Fee is $350. All dogs older than six months will be spayed/neutered prior to adoption. Dogs also have vaccines that are age appropriate, fecal check, treatment if needed, a vet physical, flea/tick treatment,  All of our dogs will be microchipped.We are a non profit no kill 501 (c)3 rescue. Please understand that we do our best to describe our dogs but often we rescue them with virtually no information about them and often our best educated guess can be challenging. Currently check or cash is preferred payment.

This litter of puppies was rescued from a high kill shelter in West Virginia where they wold have been euthanized had we not pulled them.  We estimate they are Beagle mixes based on their appearance.  In terms of breed and expected adult size, our vet techs make their best guess.  We expect these puppies to be Medium dogs as adults, or about 20-30 pounds.  They are currently 9 weeks old and weigh roughly 5 pounds.  TO ADOPT:These pups are NOT in the shelter and you MUST submit an application to smpetfinder@gmail.com to get the process started.  Go to www.smallmiraclesrescue.org and click \"How to Adopt\".  There you will find the dog/puppy application available for download. The more information you provide, the faster the process is for all of us.  Once you are approved to adopt we will schedule an appointment to see the puppy in person and you will be allowed to take it home that day.  Due to the ease of our adoption process, please apply only if you are ready to adopt right now and committed to the level of care that having a puppy requires.  If you are not ready to adopt, we totally understand - just wait to apply until you are ready.  Many of our puppies are placed less than 72 hours after the application is submitted (ex: an application submitted on a Thurs could be approved and the puppy sent home as early as Saturday). Make sure to note in the email subject line which puppy you are interested in.  I will take back up applications for every puppy in the event an adoption falls through.Adoption Fee Broken Down:Before our puppies are available for adoption, they will always be spayed or neutered, vaccinated (distemper, bordatella, rabies if age appropriate), dewormed, and stool sample checked for parasites.  Adoption fee for our puppies is $325, an additional $30 for a microchip and registration and an additional small discounted amount for a 3 month supply of heartworm preventative, priced at $20.

\"Howdy y'all my name is Kokomo, thanks for checking me out online! I came all the way to Providence Animal Center from West Virginia to have a chance at finding my forever home. I am approximately 6 years old and weigh around 60lbs.I have been hanging out in a short-term foster home and it has been so much fun! They have nothing but great things to say about me...aww shucks! This is their full review of me:-foster cat approved-LOVES her foster human sister-does well meeting most dogs-sweet & docile-a kissy girl-loves to cuddle-great in the car-crate-trainedOk now I'm blushing! Thanks guys! My bags are packed and I am all ready to find my forever family...so what are you waiting for?! I am spayed, microchipped and up-to-date on vaccines.**I will be living in luxury with my foster family until 6/27! So if you would like to set up a meeting with yours truly just email a completed adoption application to foster@providenceac.org and my people will call your people!**Hugs & slobbery kisses,KokomoProvidence Animal Center relies on adoption fees and donations to save pets! Adoption fees vary per pet. To find out this pet’s adoption fee or for more information, please call the Adoption Center with this pet’s ID number.Can’t adopt? Consider fostering or donating! Visit ProvidenceAC.org for more information on how you can support the lifesaving mission!

If you are interested in adopting this dog, please fill out our dog adoption questionnaire and e-mail it to Lindsaymrowan@gmail.com.PLEASE VISIT THIS WEBSITE TO FIND THE ADOPTION QUESTIONNAIRE: http://www.homewardtrails.org/adopt-a-pet/adoption-forms/Meet Reese! This sweet girl is originally from Fayetteville, WV where she was surrendered with her sister Heidi after her owner could no longer care for them. She's outgoing and sweet, and settling in well with her foster. We think she's nearly house-trained (only had one accident her first night there). She loves to be with her sister Heidi, they sleep intertwined and often \"groom\" each other. She loves being around people, and enjoys exploring outdoors. If you're interested in learning more about Reese or applying to adopt her, please email Lindsay.Adoption Coordinator: LindsayBreed Estimate: DachshundGender: FemaleApproximate weight: 17 lbsApproximate age: 6-7 yearsLocation: Foster HomeCratetrained: UnknownCoat Type: Short Personality: Sweet and friendlyThe adoption fee for this dog is $375 This fee INCLUDES spay/neuter and microchip. Every adopted Homeward Trails animal comes with 30 days of free pet health insurance. We are proud to partner with the following veterinarians who offer a free first exam for your animal, exclusively for HT adopters: Caring Hands Animal Hospital, Palisades Veterinary Clinic, Sunshine Animal Hospital and Clarendon Animal Care and all VCA Animal Hospitals.Additionally, any VCA hospital will cover illnesses up to $250 at no cost to any Homeward Trails adopter.We also provide a 30-minute phone consult with a professional dog trainer at Fur-Get Me Not within the first 30 days of adopting - just for HT adopters in the Arlington/Alexandria area. Start your new dog out on the right foot with this valuable, expert advice and guidance FREE!You can save animals like this one by becoming a foster! Fosters are like way stations between high kill shelters and forever homes. We need fosters so that we can save dogs before they are euthanized at the shelters. If you are interested in becoming a foster, please check out our information about fostering by visiting http://www.homewardtrails.org/foster-a-pet/dog-and-cat-foster-program/

Woo Hoo for Twenty-Two.Twenty-Two (aka Fuzzy) is a beautiful brindle, white and brown Hound mix. This guy came from West Virginia with a sibling and his Mom. His striking coat ismedium in length.Twenty-Two may have Plott Hound and/or Cattle Dog roots. He is 45 pounds and 3 years old.Fuzzy is a love bug who lives to please! He knows a few tricks and is eager to learn more sit, lay, stay and come are just a few of this boy's many talents. He is very gentle with food and treats, taking them gingerly from his trainer after he has earned them. Fuzzy shows his excitement in the cutest way by tapping his toes on the ground and wiggling his butt. He loves a good rub and snuggle with his foster parents. He is very loyal and loves to please you. His Favorite Spot is anywhere he can be near YOU!Fuzzy is house trained, crate trained, good with both dogs and cats! With a personality on the more submissive side, Fuzzy easily makes friends with new dogs and starts out cautious towards people. Once given a chance to warm up, he loves any person who will give him nice pets!Fuzzyis working on his leash training in his foster home, but likely has never been on a leash before coming to Mostly Muttz and will need a family with some patience to help him acclimate. For this reason, he will ONLY be adopted to a home with a fully fenced yard.He has learned to walk on a leash in the last few weeks but he is somewhat intimidated by surfaces that are not grass or dirt. He loves to ride in the car but needs assistance getting into it. All of this is very new to Fuzzy but he is up to learning. An adopter who has some dog experience and the patience to work with the Fuzz Man, would be ideal. He is The BEST Dog!You can apply to adopt Twenty-Two atwww.mostlymuttz.org/adoption-application/.

Do some High Kicks for Sixty-Six; aka Reese. This very nice 7-year-old, 38 pound Hound mix came from West Virginia with her two sons and other housemates. She is house-trained but is not fond of a crate. Reese gets along well with other dogs and is good with cats, as well. She lived with 5 of them. This girl walks great on a leash. She is Super Friendly and Sweet. Some of her favorite things include cuddling, being petted, lounging on the couch and trying to talk. Reese is a Great Girl who is Ready to go Home with YOU!You can apply to adopt Sixty-Six atwww.mostlymuttz.org/adoption-application/.

Yahoo and Yippee for Thirty-Three; aka Brutus. This very nice 2-year-old, 35 pound Hound mix came from West Virginia with many of his family members. He is house-trained and crate-trained. Brutus gets along well with other dogs and is good with cats, as well. He lived with 5 of them. He likely has never been on a leash and for this reason, he will ONLY be adopted to a home with a fully fenced yard.An adopter who has some dog experience and the patience to work with Thirty-Three, would be ideal. Are You the One with the Firm and Loving Home for Brutus?You can apply to adopt Thirty-Three atwww.mostlymuttz.org/adoption-application/.

Jump and Jive for Fifty-Five - we call him 50, for short. This very nice 3-year-old, 40 pound Hound mix came from West Virginia with some of his family members. He is house-trained and crate-trained.Fifty gets along with other dogs but he is somewhat selective about it. Slow introductions are a MUST for this guy. He is good with cats.Since he has been with Mostly Muttz, Fifty-Five has learned to walk fairly well on a leash. Because leash walking is new to him, Fifty will only be adopted to a home with a fully fenced yard. He rides nicely in a car, too. Fifty isa bit underweight and could stand to gain a few pounds. All in all though,he isOne Sweet Little Dude!An adopter who has some dog experience and the patience to work with Fifty-Five would be ideal. These pictures do not do him justice. He has such a magnificent coat and an outstanding personality. Life could be, Oh So Nifty, if you wanna take Home Fifty!You can apply to adopt Fifty-Five atwww.mostlymuttz.org/adoption-application/.

Divot is a sweet girl around 12 weeks old...she was rescued from a shelter in West Virginia. Her nose is a little funny, hence the name divot....our vet has said its just a birth defect. She's very sweet, loves everyone. She's about 20 lbs now so we think she'll be around 40 as an adult.Email sheplover5@aol.com for an application to adopt. Please be within an hour of Spring City PA as we do require a home visit. Divot's adoption fee is $300 plus a $100 spay deposit. We will spay her at six months -no exceptions.

Meet Rachel! Rachel is one of two beagle pups that have just been rescued from West Virginia. They are pint-sized pups that love to play and are roughly 9 weeks old. ~Please be within an hour of Spring City PA as we do require a home visit. Rachel's adoption fee is $400 which includes a$100 spay deposit. Email sheplover5@aol.com for more info.

This dog is a part of our Summer $25 Adoption Fee Promotion! In an effort to keep up with the high rescue demand this summer, we are discounting many dog adoption fees to $25! Note- standard adoption screening interview and reference checks still apply!If you are interested in adopting this dog, please fill out our dog adoption questionnaire and e-mail it to lindsaymrowan@gmail.com. PLEASE VISIT THIS WEBSITE TO FIND THE ADOPTION QUESTIONNAIRE: http://www.homewardtrails.org/adopt-a-pet/adoption-forms/Say Hi to Lucas! These cute guy comes from Fayetteville, WV. He's about 2 years old, 45 lbs and has a beautiful black and white spotted coat. He's friendly, energetic, and loves being around people. Lucas is very smart and knows lots of commands -- he's always interested in learning more tricks (for treats of course). He is house trained and crate trained and does well on his own during the day. He's still working on his leash manners and hoping that his new mom or dad can take him on walks where he can gain confidence and learn techniques to walk nicely around other dogs. His foster has been working on some great training techniques to help with pulling and barking, and is making great progress! She would be happy to help him transition and teach you techniques to be successful. He already does well meeting kids, knowing that he needs to sit and let them pet him. Lucas hopes to find a family who live in a quieter neighborhood (versus downtown) and would prefer to be the only dog in the house, he just gets so excited to meet other dogs and needs more introduction and time to behave properly. His fosters have been working him on this, and he's met a few new doggie friends already.  Contact Lindsay if you're interested in learning more about Lucas!Adoption Coordinator: LindsayBreed Estimate: Boxer/Dalmation mixGender: MaleApproximate weight: 45 lbs.Approximate age: 2 years old Location: Foster HomeCratetrained: YesCoat Type: ShortPersonality: Friendly, energeticThe adoption fee for this dog is $25. This fee INCLUDES neuter and microchip. Every adopted Homeward Trails animal comes with 30 days of free pet health insurance. We are proud to partner with the following veterinarians who offer a free first exam for your animal, exclusively for HT adopters: Caring Hands Animal Hospital, Palisades Veterinary Clinic, Sunshine Animal Hospital and Clarendon Animal Care and all VCA Animal Hospitals.Additionally, any VCA hospital will cover illnesses up to $250 at no cost to any Homeward Trails adopter.We also provide a 30-minute phone consult with a professional dog trainer at Fur-Get Me Not within the first 30 days of adopting - just for HT adopters in the Arlington/Alexandria area. Start your new dog out on the right foot with this valuable, expert advice and guidance FREE!You can save animals like this one by becoming a foster! Fosters are like way stations between high kill shelters and forever homes. We need fosters so that we can save dogs before they are euthanized at the shelters. If you are interested in becoming a foster, please check out our information about fostering by visiting http://www.homewardtrails.org/foster-a-pet/dog-and-cat-foster-program/

He is very smart, has done some obedience training, and knows basic commands. He previously lived with two kids and loved them, but is a high energy pup who needs guidance to play softly with smaller children. Hobbes may need to live in a house as he has been known to bark and could be disruptive in an apartment. Hobbes has been on a TAILS OUT outing -spending an afternoon with our volunteers where he was able to get out and explore a bit one-on-one. Babish is a 10-year-old hound mix who came to Pennsylvania from a West Virginia coal mine. She was born at that mine and was the only survivor of her litter. She is a lovingdog who craves human attention. Babish is very affectionate toward those she trusts.Babish is housebroken and loves being outside. In an outside environment, she is tolerant of other dogs. Inside the house, she is cautious with other animals. She also needs time to warm up to people. She would need to go to an adult only home.It's important for us to let everyone know about Babish's struggles.It is difficult for a dog as wary as Babish is, to find a good home. We know there is someone out there who will have the patience and understanding to let this girl become comfortable in her time.Babish has spent her entire life without a family or home. We know there is a forever home out there just for her. This girl is ready to live the good life.You can apply to adopt Babish atwww.mostlymuttz.org/adoption-application/.

Rocky and his sisters Sharon and Serena are very close - we would love to find a home that would take at least two of them. Once they know you and trust you, they are wonderful but they are scared. They need to go to a home with a secure yard and patient owners.FOSTER NEEDED ASAP!!!!!10/28/18 - rocky is now a year old......still waiting for his forever home. He's sweet but shy with new people. Looking for a home that will give him a chance!!Rocky is one of the six pups we took in from West Virginia. They were trapped and very scared pups.. They are sweet once you get to know them. We are looking for adopters or fosters who are willing to give them a chance. Rocky is about 20 lbs now and 4 months old. He needs someone to give him a chance. Email sheplover5@aol.com for more info or an application.

Fancee, also known as Fannie D (for fancy dog) came from a shelter in West Virginia.  We think she's about four.  She is a quiet, petite girl.  She has not been cat tested.  She’s great with people.  She loves to make a nest out of her bed.  She listens very well and is a people pleaser.  She literally does nothing wrongFor more information on Fancee please email suew@boxertransfer.org

Micki is a beautiful 7 year old female who comes to us from a shelter in WV. Micki spent her life producing pups, and then was thrown away. This girl needs to be an only dog, but does well with people! She is strong on a leash, but eager to please! She is currently in boarding in LaGrange, NC!

Jules is a lab mix who was born approximately April 4, 2019. He and his brother and sister came to us from a shelter in Huntington, W Va.  Jules is pretty much a typical puppy - bouncy, curious, energetic, messy, and loves everyone he meets.  Jules still has a lot of learning to do! He will need time and patience over the next several months when it comes to his house-breaking, teething, and all the puppy shenanigans he will undoubtedly get into. Please make sure that you are ready for this commitment - and also that you're willing to make Jules a member of the family for the rest of his life. If you would like to visit Jules, our shelter hours are listed at www.lifehouse4animals.org. It is best to call ahead (502-875-3436) to make sure someone will be there, as we are completely staffed by volunteers.If you have questions about this animal, please contact the adoption counselor directly at amyc0405@yahoo.com. Applications to adopt Jules can be downloaded from our website under the 'Adopt' section and emailed directly to the adoption counselor at amyc0405@yahoo.com, or can be filled out in person at the shelter. We are staffed by volunteers and are typically unable to complete the adoption process on the same day that applications are submitted. Please understand that it can sometimes take 2-4 days to process an application.
